77398:
You were born in 1965 in country 702, and now, at 55 years old, you find yourself retired or receiving a pension. Over the years, work has been a significant aspect of your life. You value work highly, believing it is both a duty towards society and should always come first—even if it means sacrificing leisure time. Your view on work is that it is essential for societal well-being, and you have consistently prioritized it. This strong sense of duty and responsibility is something you consider important for children to learn as well.

Your financial situation is quite stable. You belong to the seventh highest income group in your country, and you are largely satisfied with your household's financial situation, rating it an 8 on a scale of 1-10. Your family has saved money during the past year, and you rarely went without a cash income or needed medicine. You are moderately concerned about the potential inability to provide a good education for your children, but other than that, you have not experienced significant financial insecurity.

In terms of your personal life, family holds great importance. You are currently married, and your spouse has completed short-cycle tertiary education. Although you do not have much confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations, your family life and religious faith are central to who you are. You strongly agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay, and you believe that it is a societal duty to have children. However, you are not a member of any self-help, mutual aid, or charitable organization.

Politically, you lean slightly right, positioning yourself at a 6 on the left-right scale. You are somewhat interested in politics, though politics is not an essential part of your life. Your political views are influenced by your belief that the government should focus on strengthening defense forces and that economic growth should be the top priority for the country. You also believe that maintaining order and ensuring strong defense are key goals for the next decade.

You are not heavily involved in political activism or organizations. You would never organize political activities, events, or protests online, nor would you encourage others to take political action. However, you strongly believe that having honest elections is vital for the health of the democracy. While you somewhat support government regulation and taxation of the rich to subsidize the poor (level 8), you also place emphasis on individual responsibility, slightly preferring it over government action (level 6). You believe a balance between government responsibility and individual responsibility is crucial for a well-functioning society.

Regarding democracy, you believe that the country is fairly democratic today, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. However, you do not have much confidence in the civil service, parliament, or the police. You trust banks and the armed forces much more, and you believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are not essential to democracy (level 2). You place a moderate value on democratic processes such as voters being offered a genuine choice, but you also somewhat believe that government ownership of business and industry should increase (level 7), with a slight preference for private ownership.

You are a practicing Muslim, attending religious services weekly and praying several times a day. God is central to your life, and you strongly believe in the afterlife, including heaven and hell. You consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn and believe that the primary purpose of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies. In line with this, you are firm in your belief that homosexuality, casual sex, and abortion are never justified.

Despite your strong religious beliefs, you are not isolated in your views. You have moderate confidence in your neighborhood and trust your family, but you do not place much trust in others or in people you meet for the first time. You do not trust people of another nationality very much, nor do you have much confidence in international institutions like the International Criminal Court or the World Health Organization. You also have a relatively limited trust in the government and the political system, but you do believe that a stable economy is crucial and that economic growth should be prioritized.

While your views on social issues might seem conservative, you hold a complex view on immigration. You agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, but you also believe it increases unemployment and crime rates. Immigrants, in your opinion, neither harm nor benefit the development of the country, and you believe they should not be prioritized over local workers when jobs are scarce. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, though you do not want people of a different nationality, race, or sexual orientation in your immediate vicinity. 

Socially, you are not highly involved in organizations or group activities, nor do you engage in protests or petitions. You would never sign an electronic petition or contact a government official, and you are not a member of any sport, recreational, or educational group. You are also not active in any environmental or feminist organizations. 

Despite these factors, you still recognize the importance of a functioning and democratic society, and you believe in gradual societal improvements through reforms. You are moderately confident in journalists and media coverage, especially concerning elections, but you are wary of corruption, even in the media. You are skeptical of the idea that we depend too much on science and technology, though you do recognize the positive impact science has had on society. 

In your neighborhood, crime and violence are rare, and you feel quite secure. You also do not mind having people who speak a different language as neighbors, and you would not mind having people with AIDS as neighbors. This indicates that, while you have certain conservative views, you also have a tolerance for diversity in your community when it comes to issues like language or health status.

Finally, when it comes to society, you believe that some social reforms and changes are necessary, but you remain cautious about radical shifts. You believe that society should be improved gradually and with care, emphasizing the importance of authority and tradition in the process.
11396:
You were born in 1980 in country 124, and you consider work to be a central aspect of your life. As a full-time employee working 30 hours a week or more, you strongly believe that work is not just an essential part of your daily existence but also a duty towards society. You agree that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. Your professional life and responsibilities are deeply intertwined with your sense of identity.

Your family's financial situation appears stable, as they saved money during the past year, and no one in your family has gone without a safe shelter, cash income, or needed medical treatment in the last 12 months. You are also very satisfied with your household's financial situation and describe your state of health as very good. As the chief wage earner in your household, you carry a sense of responsibility for your family’s well-being. However, despite your economic success, you remain critical of systemic issues such as corruption in both business and government. You believe that most business executives are involved in corruption, and you think that the government is rife with corruption, including the state authorities and election officials.

Your trust in political institutions is mixed. While you have a lot of confidence in the civil service and some confidence in the courts, you are wary of political parties and have little confidence in parliament. You also do not trust the police, and your confidence in the armed forces is low. Nevertheless, you have a rather high level of confidence in your country's democratic system, rating it a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10, and you are extremely satisfied with how the political system is functioning today. However, you also believe that opposition candidates are frequently prevented from running fairly in your country’s elections, and you are concerned about the prevalence of bribery in elections. Despite these reservations, you strongly agree that elections should be free and fair, and you consider them essential for democracy.

Your political views lean slightly to the right, placing you at position 6 on the left-right scale. You believe that the government should have more responsibility to ensure everyone's well-being, but you do not support excessive government control over people's lives. You also believe that the military stepping in when the government is incompetent is essential for democracy. You consider maintaining order and fighting crime to be the most important national goals, and you advocate for having a strong leader who does not need to bother with parliament and elections. You also feel strongly that people should have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities.

Your family background is one of relative privilege. Your father belonged to the higher administrative group and had a Master's degree or equivalent, and your mother has also completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. You were raised with the understanding that hard work, responsibility, and determination are important qualities to develop. These values were instilled in you, and you consider them essential for children to learn. You also believe that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl, which reflects your more traditional views on gender roles.

While family and work are central to your life, religion also holds significant importance. You are a religious person, a Protestant, and you attend religious services weekly. You strongly believe that God is extremely important in your life and pray several times a day. However, despite your deep religious convictions, you do not consider religious faith to be an essential quality for children to learn. Instead, you place importance on other virtues such as determination, perseverance, and unselfishness. You also believe in life after death, heaven, and hell, seeing the basic meaning of religion as making sense of life in this world rather than focusing on life after death.

Your social views reflect some contradictions. On one hand, you strongly believe in the importance of democracy, with civil rights protecting people from state oppression being an absolute essential characteristic of democracy. You also advocate for equality, believing that women should have the same rights as men and supporting the concept of honest elections. On the other hand, you hold some controversial and conservative views. For instance, you believe that a man beating his wife is almost always justified, a stance that many would find troubling. Similarly, you support the idea of parents beating children, though with less intensity.

You are cautious and somewhat distrustful of immigrants, believing that they negatively impact your country’s development, culture, and economy. You also hold an ambiguous stance on whether immigration increases crime or offers a better life to people from poor countries. While you believe that immigrants often increase unemployment and increase the risks of terrorism, you also agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. This reflects a complex and somewhat contradictory view on immigration and its effects on society.

In terms of your neighborhood, you feel relatively safe and secure. You have not experienced crime or safety issues in your area, and neither you nor your family has been victims of crime in the last year. While street violence, robberies, and drug sales are not common in your neighborhood, you do note that alcohol consumption in public areas occurs frequently.

You are not a member of any humanitarian, charitable, or environmental organizations, though you have signed electronic petitions and supported political causes online. Despite not being actively involved in any group, you care about the political and social direction of your country. You consider yourself somewhat interested in politics and have taken part in political actions, whether by encouraging others to vote or to take political action online.

When it comes to personal matters, you are currently single and do not have a strong preference for neighbors based on their ethnicity or background. You would not mind having people who speak a different language as neighbors, though you would prefer not to have heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. Similarly, you are opposed to having homosexuals or people of a different race living next to you. You find these stances reflective of your discomfort with difference, even as you maintain that diversity can enrich a society.

In terms of societal progress, you place a high value on economic growth and the creation of jobs. You believe that economic growth should be the most important national goal, even if it means sacrificing the environment to some extent. You also place a significant emphasis on the development of technology, seeing it as a positive force that will provide more opportunities for future generations. However, you feel that the country’s economic system should include some degree of government ownership of businesses and industries, advocating for more state control over the economy while supporting limited private ownership.

Overall, you feel that your life is fulfilling, as you are quite satisfied with your financial situation, your family’s well-being, and your personal health. You have substantial confidence in your ability to make decisions about your life, feeling that you have control over how things unfold. Despite some contradictions in your views, you are generally content with how things are going in your life and in the political landscape, although you remain critical of certain aspects, particularly corruption in both business and government.
71483:
You were born in 1938, in country 630. Your family has always been an important part of your life, and you have strong ties to both your country and your hometown. You feel close to your village, town, or city, and have a deep sense of connection to your country and continent. Your mother, born in country 630, completed primary education, while your father, who worked as a farm laborer, also completed primary education. 

Work has played a central role in your life, and you believe strongly that work is a duty toward society. You are retired now, receiving a pension after working for a government or public institution. Your income places you in the eighth-highest income group in your country, and overall, you are satisfied with the financial situation of your household, rating it an 8 out of 10. You consider yourself a religious person and belong to the Roman Catholic denomination, with God being very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day and believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others, rather than follow religious norms and ceremonies. You strongly believe in the afterlife, holding firm beliefs in both heaven and hell.

You have a bachelor's degree or equivalent, and so does your spouse. Your spouse is or was self-employed, and you were not the chief wage earner in your household. Together, you managed to provide for your family, and you never went without a safe shelter, needed medicine, or medical treatment. You have also saved money during the past year, and you consider thrift, saving money, and planning important qualities for children to learn. 

When it comes to your political beliefs, you are somewhat interested in politics but would describe it as not very important in your life. You are not a member of any political party, labor union, or any environmental, art, music, or educational organizations. You place your political views at position 6 on the left-right scale, leaning slightly right. You believe your country is extremely democratic in how it is being governed today, rating it a 9 out of 10. You are committed to democracy, strongly believing that having honest elections, voting in free elections, and ensuring equal rights for men and women are absolutely essential to the democratic system. You also believe civil rights protecting people from state oppression are a fundamental characteristic of democracy. However, you hold a rather neutral stance on issues like immigration and unemployment benefits, finding it hard to form strong opinions on whether immigration increases crime or if unemployment aid is a necessary feature of democracy.

Your opinions on various aspects of democracy and government lean towards valuing security over freedom, as you consider security more important if given the choice. You are not worried about losing your job, but you do feel that there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), though you believe few of the state authorities are involved in corruption. Despite this, you hold quite a lot of confidence in your government, courts, and the armed forces, although you have very little confidence in parliament, the civil service, major companies, political parties, or the International Monetary Fund. You are somewhat worried about terrorism and civil wars, but you have confidence in humanitarian organizations like Amnesty International.

You have a strong sense of responsibility and believe it is a crucial quality for children to learn. You do not consider imagination, independence, or obedience important qualities for children to learn, but you place high importance on values like tolerance, respect for others, and determination. You consider yourself to be somewhat cautious when dealing with people, feeling that you need to be very careful with those you meet for the first time, as you generally do not trust people easily. Trust in people you know personally is somewhat stronger, but you would still be cautious.

In terms of social issues, you believe that issues such as domestic violence and terrorism are never justified, and you are against the idea of prostitution and casual sex. You also believe that a man beating his wife is never justified, and that violence against others is never acceptable. While you are not a fan of immigration, you do not see it as having a particularly negative or positive impact on your country, feeling that immigrants neither strengthen nor harm the country's development. You also do not agree that immigration leads to social conflict or that immigrants should be given priority when jobs are scarce. 

Your views on marriage and family are similarly conservative. You believe that sex before marriage is never justified, and while divorce is somewhat not justified in your eyes, you are open to exceptions. You believe that the role of a mother working for pay can negatively affect children, though you disagree with the notion that work should always come first, even at the expense of spare time. 

Regarding your personal life, you value leisure time, but not at the expense of duty and work. Your health, while fair, is not something you are overly concerned about at this stage in life, and you would rate your level of happiness as fairly good, though you are neither completely satisfied nor dissatisfied with how things are in your country politically. 

You are strongly opposed to euthanasia, suicide, and terrorism, all of which you believe are never justified. You also do not believe that it is justified to claim government benefits one is not entitled to or to avoid paying public transport fares. You have a somewhat moderate belief that hard work leads to a better life, though you attribute some of it to luck and connections.

Overall, you consider your society to need gradual improvement through reforms. You have a great deal of confidence in charitable organizations and feel that these groups, along with religious organizations, play an important role in bettering society. You find it difficult to trust the media but do believe that some journalists provide fair coverage, especially during elections.

You do not obtain information from social media, preferring traditional outlets like TV and radio news. You have a general belief in science, but you think we rely on it too much and not enough on faith. Despite your belief that science has its benefits, you do not see it as making life significantly easier or healthier. You are somewhat opposed to the further development of technology, feeling that more emphasis on it could have negative consequences.

Your neighborhood is generally safe, with no frequent occurrences of crime, drug sales, or street violence. You do not mind having people of different races, nationalities, or sexual orientations as neighbors, showing a level of openness to diversity, though you still hold some reservations about homosexual couples and their ability to be good parents.

As a person who values family, work, and faith, your life has been shaped by your strong beliefs, commitment to democracy, and a sense of responsibility toward both society and the next generation.
83811:
You were born in 1977 in country 788. Your upbringing was grounded in a deep belief in the importance of family and work. As a housewife, you have a strong sense of responsibility towards your family, especially when it comes to your children’s upbringing. You consider certain qualities crucial for their development, such as a sense of responsibility, independence, hard work, religious faith, determination, perseverance, unselfishness, obedience, and tolerance. You believe these are essential values to instill, ensuring that they grow up with strong moral and personal foundations. 

While your mother had little formal education and your father completed primary education, you come from a background where education was highly valued, but not necessarily in an academic sense. Your father worked in the higher administrative group, possibly in a position such as a banker or high government official, which likely provided a stable income for your family. However, you do not feel a particular sense of closeness to the world or to your continent, emphasizing instead local ties, especially to your village, town, or city. 

You are now 42 years old and have lived through changes that have shaped your views on society. You believe work is central to one’s life and should come first, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. This belief is mirrored in your personal life; you see work as a duty to society. Though you have never held a job outside of your home, your husband, who is or was self-employed, is a key contributor to the family’s income. You belong to the sixth highest income group in your country, and while you feel somewhat satisfied with your household's financial situation, you understand that your family "just got by" last year. Despite this, you have never experienced a lack of shelter, medical treatment, or income, showcasing the stability in your life.

On the topic of democracy and governance, you are moderately satisfied with the political system in your country, rating it a 7 on a scale of 1-10. However, you feel there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (rated 6 out of 10), with few local and state authorities involved in it. Your trust in the civil service, government, parliament, banks, political parties, and other major institutions is low. You do not have very much confidence in the courts, the police, the International Criminal Court, or even charitable organizations, demonstrating a general skepticism towards authority and institutions. You believe that journalists and the media, like politicians and other officials, are frequently involved in corruption.

You feel a sense of duty towards society, which reflects in your views on political participation. Although you would never organize political activities or protests online, you have encouraged others to vote, even though you have never signed a petition or donated to any campaigns. You do not feel strongly about political activism, yet you are somewhat interested in politics and might encourage others to act, though you have not yet done so yourself.

You place your political views at position 6 on the left-right scale, leaning slightly to the right. You strongly agree that men are better suited for business and political leadership than women, reflecting a more traditional perspective on gender roles. You do not consider the equal rights of women to be an essential feature of democracy, ranking it a mere 4 on a scale of 1-10. Additionally, you believe that men make better business executives and political leaders than women. These views indicate a clear stance on gender that does not align with progressive ideals.

When it comes to other social issues, your beliefs remain quite traditional. For instance, you moderately believe that science and technology have a positive impact on our lives, though you also think we depend too much on science and not enough on faith. You are moderately supportive of private ownership of businesses but believe that there should be greater emphasis on the development of technology. You do not mind having people from different races, languages, or religions as neighbors, but you are not entirely comfortable with immigrants or foreign workers in your neighborhood. Despite this, you believe immigrants contribute positively to your country’s development and do not think they significantly increase the crime rate or social conflict. 

You have a nuanced perspective on personal freedoms and security, leaning more toward prioritizing security over freedom. You believe in God and attend religious services weekly. Religion plays a significant role in your life, as you place a high value on God’s importance. The basic meaning of religion, for you, is to do good to others rather than following religious norms and ceremonies. You believe that religious faith is an important quality to teach children, and you hold firm beliefs about life after death, heaven, and hell.

Your approach to social issues is equally grounded in traditional values. For instance, you believe that having casual sex, sex before marriage, abortion, euthanasia, and prostitution are mostly not justified. You view violence, including terrorism and the beating of wives or children, as generally not justified. Furthermore, you do not find divorce, suicide, or claiming government benefits without entitlement to be acceptable behavior. You maintain a relatively conservative stance on morality, believing that people should obey their rulers and that the state’s role in making incomes equal is slightly essential for democracy.

Though you trust people you meet for the first time somewhat, you tend to be cautious and somewhat skeptical of others, reflecting a broader wariness about society. You believe that when jobs are scarce, local citizens should be prioritized over immigrants, and you think that people should take more responsibility for themselves, though government support is also necessary. You are not overly concerned about losing your job or not finding one, and you feel secure in your daily life. 

Despite your general skepticism toward certain institutions, you value the role of the military in securing your country’s defense, which you believe should be the most important goal in the next decade. You also believe in the importance of having strong defense forces and feel it would be good to have more respect for authority in society.

Your feelings about your country’s democracy are mixed. While you believe that free elections are essential, you also feel that having strong defense forces and the ability for voters to choose their leaders in those elections are crucial for the functioning of democracy. You rate civil rights protection and government’s right to collect information as somewhat essential characteristics of democracy but also believe that it’s important for people to feel they have freedom of choice and control over their lives. However, you do not trust your neighborhood, as street violence and fights do occur somewhat frequently. 

Your views are also reflective of a moderately conservative stance on moral and ethical issues. You are skeptical of the role of science in shaping society and value faith more. While you do not mind having heavy drinkers, homosexuals, or drug addicts as neighbors, you believe that certain behaviors like cheating on taxes, violence, and taking bribes are usually not justified.

All in all, you consider yourself to be rather happy with your life, although you feel that society could gradually improve through reforms rather than drastic changes.
36049:
You were born in 1997 in country 360. At 20 years old, you are currently employed full-time, working 30 hours or more a week. You belong to the lowest income group in your country, and despite your financial situation, you feel that you are better off compared to your parents when they were your age. You believe strongly in the value of hard work and prioritize work above all else, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. Work is central to your life, and you view it as a duty toward society. Family is also very important to you, and you share a close relationship with your family. Your father belongs to the semi-skilled worker group, such as a bus driver, bricklayer, or carpenter, and has completed primary education. Your mother, on the other hand, was born in your country and also has completed primary education. Both your parents have worked hard, and you value the lessons they've imparted on responsibility and hard work.

You have a complex view of democracy and governance. While you strongly believe that civil rights, particularly protection from state oppression, are an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10), you also believe that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness over being democratic (level 1). You view the governance in your country as completely democratic (level 10), but you also believe that corruption is quite prevalent in your country, with widespread corruption in both government and business. Despite this, you hold a great deal of confidence in the civil service, as well as in organizations like the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization, while maintaining little faith in banks, political parties, and the European Union. You are skeptical about elections, often believing they are not fair or transparent, and you believe that voters are frequently bribed in your country’s elections. However, you do value having honest elections and see it as a significant goal for your country.

You place your political views firmly on the right side of the spectrum, with your beliefs rooted in the idea that competition is harmful (level 10) and that government should have a greater role in business ownership (level 10). You are a member of a humanitarian or charitable organization, though not actively involved, and you believe strongly that government ownership of business and industry should be increased. While you do not trust many aspects of society, including the media, police, and banks, you have significant confidence in charitable organizations, the courts, and the armed forces.

When it comes to societal issues, you believe in traditional values. For instance, you think that men make better business executives than women, and you hold the view that men are generally better political leaders than women. You also strongly believe in the importance of religion and view God as central to your life. You attend religious services regularly and pray several times a day. Religion, for you, is about making sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife, and you consider yourself a deeply religious person. This belief influences your views on social issues, as you believe that prostitution, homosexuality, abortion, euthanasia, and terrorism are never justified.

Although you consider yourself a religious person, you do not believe in heaven or hell, nor in life after death. You also do not believe in the importance of imagination or tolerance as qualities for children to learn, though you place great emphasis on independence, responsibility, and obedience as essential virtues for children.

Social issues, particularly crime, are another area where you have strong views. You believe that crime is an important concern, and the fight against it ranks second in terms of priority for your country. However, you feel relatively secure, and neither you nor your family has been a victim of crime in the past year. Your neighborhood experiences occasional alcohol consumption and street violence, but robberies and drug sales are not frequent.

Your approach to immigration is one of skepticism. You believe that immigrants have a negative impact on the development of your country and disagree with the idea that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You also do not believe that immigration provides a better life for people from poor countries, and you believe it may even increase risks of terrorism and crime. Nevertheless, you are open to having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors and do not mind having people who speak a different language.

Your views on social issues extend to personal relationships as well. You believe that violence against others, including domestic abuse, is never justified, and you hold the same stance against sexual harassment, divorce, and casual sex. For you, marriage should be a sacred institution, and sex before marriage is never justified. Similarly, you strongly believe that people should take responsibility for providing for themselves and that government welfare is not an essential feature of democracy.

Your health is generally fair, and you report no significant issues with accessing medical care or missing necessary treatments. However, you are quite concerned about the potential for losing your job and the challenges of finding stable work. Although you do not consider yourself politically active, you are occasionally involved in local religious or charitable organizations, but you are not a member of any political or environmental groups.

In terms of values, you prioritize stability and security, believing that maintaining order in the nation and ensuring economic growth should be the highest priorities for your country. You also consider the idea of having experts make decisions about the country's future over government-led decision-making as a positive step.

You have a moderate amount of freedom in shaping your life’s outcomes, but you feel that there is significant risk in giving or receiving bribes, which you consider to be a widespread issue in your country. Your skepticism about the political system is reflected in your lack of trust in both politicians and public institutions, including parliament and the police.

In conclusion, you are a young person who values work, tradition, and religion, and who holds strong, conservative views about society. While you are skeptical of many modern political systems and institutions, you firmly believe in the importance of hard work, government control over business, and maintaining order.
32099:
You were born in the year 1934 in country 156. As an 84-year-old, you have witnessed significant changes in the world over your lifetime, but some things remain constant. Family holds a central place in your life, and you highly value the relationships you have with your loved ones. You are currently retired and rely on a pension for your income. Despite being part of the lowest income group in your country, you feel that your standard of living is better than your parents' was at your age.

Work has always been important to you, and you believe in the duty of contributing to society through your labor. You were involved in government or public service work at some point in your life. Even in retirement, you continue to be active in various organizations, particularly those with humanitarian or charitable goals. You are also very involved in religious organizations, attending church services once a week and placing great importance on the role of God in your life. Although you consider yourself not religious, you also firmly believe in the importance of faith and prayer.

You have a deep sense of responsibility, which you consider an important quality for children to learn. You also value independence and tolerance, emphasizing the need for children to understand these values. However, you do not consider imagination, perseverance, or thrift to be as important for children to learn. As you reflect on the state of the world today, you believe the most important goal for the future of your country is economic growth, with progress toward a more humane society ranking second. You also see the beautification of cities and the countryside as a priority for the next decade.

Politically, you place yourself at the center of the left-right scale, maintaining moderate views. You are not overly enthusiastic about the functioning of the political system, often feeling dissatisfied with how it operates. You believe that the country is governed democratically, but you are critical of corruption at various levels of government. You feel that most business executives are involved in corruption, and you strongly believe that corruption is widespread in your country. This belief extends to most of the state and local authorities, in which you have very little confidence.

You value democracy deeply, and having free elections with honest officials is very important to you. However, you do not trust political parties or the government as a whole. You believe that most voters are often bribed, and you feel there is a substantial risk of facing consequences for accepting or offering bribes in exchange for public services. This corruption leaves you disillusioned with much of the state apparatus, including the courts, civil service, and police. You do not have much confidence in elections, but you consistently vote in both national and local elections, believing that citizens should have a genuine choice in selecting their leaders.

You hold traditional views on social issues. For instance, you believe that a man beating his wife is never justified and that violence against others is always wrong. You also oppose casual sex, sexual harassment, and prostitution, considering them unacceptable. However, you have more nuanced views on other aspects of family life, such as divorce and child-rearing. You believe that while parents should not beat their children, there may be situations where it is somewhat justified. You also think that a mother working for pay may affect her children negatively. Your opinion on euthanasia, however, is clear: you believe it is always justified.

Your views on immigration are more complex. While you think immigrants contribute positively to the development of the country, you also believe that immigration increases crime rates and leads to social conflict. You feel that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to citizens over immigrants. You also hold concerns about the impact of immigration on unemployment and terrorism. Although you do not think immigrants should be prevented from running for election, you strongly believe in maintaining strict control over immigration.

You have a somewhat cynical view of the role of science and technology in modern life. While you agree that they make life easier and more comfortable, you also feel that they break down people's sense of right and wrong. You moderately believe that we rely too much on science and not enough on faith, and that science will create more opportunities for future generations. You do not, however, support the idea that scientific advancements should take precedence over other social values, such as protecting the environment or promoting moral conduct.

Your general sense of security in life is not very high. While you have not felt unsafe from crime or violence in your immediate surroundings, you are worried about issues like terrorism, civil war, and the potential collapse of democracy. You feel that the basic rights of individuals should be protected from state oppression, and you have confidence in international organizations like the World Health Organization and the International Criminal Court to uphold these values. However, you do not trust the police or the government to protect your rights as effectively as you would like.

In terms of your family life, you are widowed, and you deeply value the role of family in your life. You have not experienced significant financial hardship in recent years, but you and your family have just gotten by. You have not been the victim of crime, nor have your family members been, in the past year. Despite the challenges you have faced, you maintain a sense of optimism about your loved ones and the value of family bonds.

Overall, your worldview is shaped by a combination of traditional values, skepticism about government and institutions, and a strong belief in the importance of religious faith and social responsibility. You hold a critical eye toward societal progress, believing that while economic growth and security are vital, they must not come at the expense of human dignity and the well-being of future generations.
97197:
You were born in 1988 in country 716 and currently reside in your home country. At 32 years old, you consider work to be a central aspect of your life, with a strong belief that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. You are self-employed and serve as the chief wage earner in your household. Despite your commitment to work, leisure time holds a significant place in your life, but it is not as crucial as your professional responsibilities. You believe that economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority for the country, even at the cost of the environment.

Your financial situation is somewhat of a concern, as you rate your satisfaction with your household's finances at a level of 4 on a scale of 1-10. You belong to the sixth highest income group in your country, but you're still somewhat dissatisfied with the financial stability of your household. Despite these concerns, your family rarely experienced financial hardship, having never gone without needed medicine or medical treatment in the last 12 months, nor have you or your family gone without a safe shelter or cash income.

Family is very important to you. Your mother and father both completed upper secondary education, and your mother was born in your home country, while your father was born in country 716. You feel close to your family and value the lessons they have imparted. You believe that children should learn qualities like a sense of responsibility, hard work, religious faith, and tolerance and respect for others. However, you do not consider qualities such as independence, imagination, or perseverance to be particularly important for children to learn. You also strongly believe that work is the most important quality for children to learn.

Your views on society and politics reveal a complex perspective. You consider your country somewhat undemocratic (level 4 on a scale of 1-10) and have little confidence in the government, parliament, civil service, or the courts. You do not trust the police at all and have very little faith in banks or major companies. You believe that most civil service providers and local authorities are involved in corruption, and that there is a moderate amount of corruption in your country (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You consider a high level of economic growth to be essential for the country, yet you place little trust in politicians or political parties. You are not interested in politics, do not consider it important, and do not engage in political activities, either online or offline.

Despite your mistrust in government institutions, you do believe in the importance of democracy. You believe in the essential characteristics of democracy, such as having free elections (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), ensuring civil rights for all people (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and upholding the rights of women (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, your belief in the importance of individual freedoms over state intervention is tempered by your skepticism toward the system as a whole.

Your religious faith is an integral part of your life. You belong to the Roman Catholic denomination and attend religious services once a week. God holds great importance in your life, ranking at level 10 on a scale of 1-10. You believe in both heaven and hell, and that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death rather than in this world. You also believe in the value of religious faith for children, though you do not view it as essential for everyone to follow religious norms or ceremonies.

While you hold conservative values regarding moral issues, your views on social topics, such as immigration, reveal a more pragmatic outlook. You agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and offers people from poorer countries a better life. However, you also acknowledge that immigration can increase unemployment, social conflict, and even the risk of terrorism. You do not believe that immigrants have either a particularly good or bad impact on your country's development. You are neutral about their contribution to society and its future.

You are deeply concerned with crime in your neighborhood, where alcohol consumption, robberies, and drug sales occur frequently. Despite these concerns, you and your family rarely felt unsafe from crime in the last 12 months, and you have not been the victim of any crime. You also trust your neighborhood completely and have a strong sense of connection to your community. Yet, you remain vigilant and have avoided going out at night for security reasons, and you would never carry a weapon for protection.

Regarding social justice and equality, you take a firm stance. You believe that issues such as violence, corruption, and cheating are never justified under any circumstances. You oppose casual sex, sex before marriage, and prostitution, considering all of these actions to be completely unjustifiable. You also strongly believe that sexual harassment and domestic violence are never acceptable. Your belief in upholding moral integrity extends to issues like claiming government benefits you are not entitled to, which you also consider never justified.

Despite your concerns about crime and security, you do not feel particularly secure these days. However, you remain committed to maintaining order in your country and believe that fighting crime should be a top priority. You also believe in the importance of keeping people's incomes equal, which you consider an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy. At the same time, you support the notion that people who work hard should be rewarded, and that individual effort should be incentivized.

Although you are somewhat dissatisfied with the political system, you are not completely disconnected from civic participation. You occasionally obtain information from the media, such as TV news and the Internet, but do not rely on social media or friends for political discussions. You may donate to campaigns or contact government officials but would never sign an electronic petition or encourage political action online.

You are moderately confident in international organizations, such as the International Criminal Court, the World Health Organization, and the European Union, and believe in their role in promoting global stability and justice. Despite your limited trust in national institutions, you have a great deal of confidence in charitable organizations, the International Monetary Fund, and universities. You also feel a sense of connection to your continent, region, and country and believe in the importance of honest elections.

Overall, you consider yourself a religious person who is rather happy with your life, despite some dissatisfaction with the political and financial situations in your country. You are strongly committed to your work and family and value hard work as a core principle in life. Although you hold conservative views on many social issues, you are pragmatic in your approach to society and politics, balancing your religious beliefs with a deep concern for the future of your country.
29257:
You were born in the year -5, in country 826, and have grown up in a household where family is very important. Both of your parents were born in this country, and your mother was born in country -4. You are a self-employed individual who works in the private business sector, likely within the higher administrative group, which includes roles like a banker, executive in big business, or a high government official.

Work is crucial to you, and you consider it a key part of your identity, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. You believe that work should always come first, even if it means having less spare time, and you hold the view that hard work usually leads to a better life, although you attribute minimal importance to luck and connections. Your financial situation is very satisfactory, as you rank yourself among the second-highest income group in your country. You find that your standard of living today is about the same as that of your parents when they were your age, and your family spent some savings during the past year.

You are not particularly religious and do not belong to any religious organization or denomination. You identify as an atheist and do not believe in God, heaven, or hell. You also do not pray or attend religious services regularly. Despite this, you strongly believe in protecting freedom of speech and see it as the second most important goal for your country. Your political views place you at a neutral point on the left-right scale, and you consider politics to be of moderate importance in your life. While you are not a member of any political parties or religious organizations, you are a member of a humanitarian or charitable organization, though you are not active.

In terms of your political beliefs, you are very supportive of democratic principles. You believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are absolutely essential to democracy and strongly agree that having honest elections is crucial. You also view free elections and people choosing their leaders as essential for democracy. You hold the government to high standards, but your confidence in it is quite low, and you have no confidence in political parties, parliament, or the armed forces. While you do not feel very close to your continent or the world at large, you do feel very connected to your country and region.

You view progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society as very important, ranking it second in terms of priorities for your country over the next decade. You also strongly agree that ordinary people like yourself should have more influence over decisions in their workplaces and communities. You are not opposed to political activism, and you might encourage others to take action, whether by voting, signing petitions, or taking online political action.

When it comes to your stance on societal issues, you are highly liberal and open-minded. You strongly believe that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, and you have a very supportive view of gay rights. You do not mind having homosexuals, immigrants, people of different races, or even drug addicts as neighbors. You are also open to having people who speak different languages as neighbors. You believe that society should become more tolerant, and respect for others is an important quality for children to learn.

You hold progressive views on social issues like abortion, divorce, and euthanasia. You believe that divorce is always justified, and that euthanasia is almost always justified. However, you have a more moderate stance on issues like prostitution and abortion, finding both somewhat unjustified. Your strong belief in personal freedom extends to the belief that individuals should have the right to make their own choices about their bodies and lives. You are strongly opposed to violence, seeing it as never justified under any circumstances.

While you strongly believe in the importance of science and technology for improving society, you also express concerns about the reliance on science over faith, disagreeing slightly with the notion that we depend too much on science. You see science and technology as critical drivers of health, comfort, and opportunities, but you do not mind a bit more emphasis on the development of technology, even if it means slower economic growth or some loss of jobs. Your opinion is that in the long run, hard work is more important than luck or connections, and you strongly believe that science and technology will create more opportunities for future generations.

Despite your relatively high level of confidence in various organizations like the World Health Organization, the International Criminal Court, and the civil service, you do not have very much confidence in the European Union, major companies, or universities. You are also somewhat skeptical about the role of the media and journalists, as you believe that journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections and that most journalists are involved in corruption.

You strongly oppose corruption and unethical behavior, such as accepting bribes or cheating on taxes. You believe that the government should not have the right to monitor individuals without their knowledge, and you consider this an essential aspect of democratic governance. Furthermore, you trust your neighborhood and family completely, and you are confident in organizations like banks and charitable groups. However, you feel that there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country, though you do not believe that most of the business executives or state authorities are involved.

While you have moderate political interest, you believe that the state making people's incomes equal is not an essential characteristic of democracy. You prefer a system with minimal support for income equality, and you believe in providing greater incentives for individual effort, even if that means less support for government responsibility. You also strongly disagree with the idea that there should be an emphasis on the development of the economy at the expense of environmental protection.

In terms of social issues, you believe that immigration neither positively nor negatively impacts the development of your country, but you agree that it strengthens cultural diversity. You also find it hard to say whether immigration increases crime, unemployment, or terrorism risks, but you agree that immigration offers people from poorer countries a better life. You are moderately concerned about the effects of immigration on social conflict, but you do not mind the presence of immigrants or foreign workers in your neighborhood.

Overall, you believe in a society that gradually improves through reforms, emphasizing the importance of a stable economy, protection of individual freedoms, and the development of a tolerant, just, and democratic society. Despite your mixed feelings about the effectiveness of institutions and the political process, you maintain an optimistic outlook on your life, and you are generally very happy. You feel secure, confident in your community, and empowered in your ability to shape your future.
30496:
You were born in 1965 in country 300, and you’ve spent your life balancing your personal beliefs with the realities of your surroundings. You are 52 years old, and your family is an essential part of your life. Family means a lot to you, and you feel very close to your country, your region, and your village. Your mother was born in the same country and had no formal education, which you contrast with your own life experiences. You completed upper secondary education, and you are currently married to someone who also completed upper secondary education. While you have not had to worry about basic needs like shelter, medicine, or a cash income in the past year, your family’s financial situation could be better, as you belong to the fourth-lowest income group in your country. You do not belong to any religious, political, or charitable organizations and prefer to live a life that is relatively independent from large, organized groups.

You are currently unemployed, and your family’s financial situation last year was only enough to just get by. Despite this, you believe in the importance of hard work, both as an individual and in the lessons it can provide for children. However, you hold a mixed view about whether hard work is generally the key to success, placing more importance on luck and connections. This nuanced view reflects your skepticism about many societal structures, such as the civil service, the political system, and the media. You have no confidence in banks, major companies, political parties, the International Monetary Fund, or the European Union. In fact, you believe corruption is widespread across all state authorities, with a significant amount of corruption in both local authorities and the media.

Your trust in people, institutions, and the government is low. You strongly disagree with the notion that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith, yet you acknowledge that science and technology make our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable. Despite this, you place greater faith in your religion than in scientific advancements. You consider yourself religious and attend religious services once a month, but your belief in the afterlife is more focused on heaven rather than life after death. You also believe in God but prefer a more practical, earthly approach to religion—emphasizing doing good to others over following religious norms.

You are politically moderate, as evidenced by your position on the left-right scale, where you place yourself at position 5 (the center). You are not very interested in politics, but you do engage with it through information channels such as TV news (which you watch daily) and talking with friends or colleagues (which happens weekly). You have a certain trust in elections, but you believe that voters are often bribed and that the media fails to offer fair coverage. You also disagree with the idea that there should be greater respect for authority in society, suggesting that you value a system of governance that ensures fairness and freedom rather than one where power is centralized. While you do not encourage others to vote or take political action online, you do have strong beliefs about democracy—particularly about the importance of civil rights, the equal rights of women, and free elections.

Your views on democracy are somewhat skeptical, with a moderate belief that your country’s democratic system functions adequately (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You hold the civil rights that protect people from state oppression as absolutely essential to democracy (level 10), but you’re more ambivalent when it comes to the state's role in regulating economic equality. For example, you somewhat believe that incomes should be made more equal, but with an emphasis on individual incentives. You also somewhat agree that government should take more responsibility for ensuring that everyone is provided for, while still placing some importance on individual responsibility.

You hold a clear stance on several social issues. You believe that men should never beat their wives (level 1), and you consider it absolutely unjustifiable for parents to beat their children (level 1). You also feel that prostitution, suicide, and euthanasia are never justified (level 1 for all). While you agree that the world should be developed through gradual reforms, you have no interest in political activism online, and you would never organize a political event or petition.

You do not mind having people from diverse backgrounds, races, and nationalities as neighbors, including those with AIDS, different languages, and immigrants. However, you believe that immigration brings several challenges. You think it leads to social conflict, increases the crime rate, and impacts unemployment. You also believe that immigration increases the risks of terrorism, although you acknowledge that it offers people from poor countries a better life. Despite these concerns, you agree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You think that immigrants should not be given priority over the local population when jobs are scarce.

When it comes to personal behaviors, you tend to have conservative views. You do not find casual sex or sex before marriage justifiable (level 1 and 6, respectively), and you also believe that homosexual couples are not as good parents as other couples (level 2). You do not mind having homosexuals or heavy drinkers as neighbors but do not wish to live near drug addicts or people who are violent. You are firm in your belief that people should never accept bribes, and you think that people who cheat on taxes or avoid paying public transport fares are never justified in doing so.

Your views on children’s education align with your own experiences in life. You believe that children should learn important values such as responsibility, independence, imagination, and hard work, while you do not see qualities like determination, thrift, or tolerance as essential. You believe that economic growth should be a priority for your country, even if it comes at the expense of the environment, and you think that maintaining order in the nation is the most important goal for the next decade. You also feel that ensuring the country has strong defense forces should be a priority.

You trust your family above all, but you do not have strong trust in others, especially those you do not know well. You have mixed views on competition, leaning slightly toward seeing it as a good force in society, but you do not believe that men are better suited for business or political leadership roles than women. You also disagree with the idea that work should always come first, even at the cost of spare time, and you place value on leisure time.

In sum, your life is shaped by a mix of personal faith, a strong commitment to family and community, a deeply ingrained skepticism toward institutions, and a conservative yet moderate outlook on politics and social issues. You trust your family above all, hold to traditional moral values, and believe in the gradual improvement of society through reforms. Despite your criticisms of the status quo, you retain a belief in democracy, albeit one that’s far from perfect, and in a system that prioritizes stability and fair representation.
97081:
You were born in 1966 in Country 716, where you have lived for most of your life. Family holds great significance to you, and you place immense value on both your immediate family and your broader sense of familial ties. Your parents' backgrounds shaped your worldview significantly. Your father worked as a semi-skilled laborer, such as a bricklayer or bus driver, and your mother had limited formal education, only completing early childhood education. Despite these modest beginnings, you find the standards of living between your generation and your parents' generation to be quite stark. When comparing your current standard of living with your parents' at your age, you feel worse off.

Your work life is central to your identity. You are currently employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more, and you deeply believe that work is an essential duty towards society. For you, work isn't just about earning a living; it is about contributing to the well-being of the nation. You take pride in your role as the chief wage earner in your household. However, economic security is a constant concern. You've often found yourself worried about not being able to provide a good education for your children or about losing your job. You also frequently feel insecure about your financial situation, describing it as very unsatisfactory. This financial anxiety stems from your family's struggles with cash income and medical care, which you or your family have often lacked in the past year.

Your political and social views reflect a strong conviction that your country is not governed democratically. You believe that the government and its institutions are deeply corrupt, and you have little to no confidence in the civil service, parliament, or the police. Corruption is rampant in your country, with you believing that most local authorities, state authorities, and business executives are involved in it. You feel that most journalists provide biased coverage of elections, and you view the electoral process in your country as deeply flawed. In fact, you do not believe the elections in your country offer a genuine choice for voters, and you distrust both election officials and political parties entirely. You also believe that voters are often bribed in these elections, and the opposition is frequently prevented from running for office.

Despite your disillusionment with the political system, you still believe strongly in the principles of democracy. You think that having honest elections and a government that ensures the equal rights of men and women are essential characteristics of democracy. Furthermore, you strongly support the idea that governments should tax the rich and subsidize the poor. You consider this to be an essential trait for a democratic nation, as well as the protection of civil rights from state oppression. You also feel strongly that economic growth should be a primary national goal, even at the expense of the environment.

You have a skeptical view of international organizations and political structures. You believe that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness over democracy, and you don't place much confidence in institutions like the European Union or the International Criminal Court. When it comes to organizations such as the United Nations, you don't believe India is a member of the United Nations Security Council, reflecting a critical stance on global political dynamics.

On social issues, you take a firm conservative stance. You believe that a man beating his wife or parents beating children is never justified. Additionally, you are steadfast in your belief that sex before marriage, casual sex, prostitution, and abortion are never justified. You also feel that divorce is unjustifiable. You believe that the notion of family is central to societal well-being, and you hold traditional values about relationships and morality. You are firm in the idea that responsibility, hard work, and religious faith are essential qualities for children to learn. 

Despite your concerns about crime and corruption, you do not feel very unsafe in your immediate surroundings. Robberies are frequent in your neighborhood, and you or your family have been victims of crime in the past year, yet you do not feel that you are at risk of violent crime or street violence. However, you do take precautions and have avoided going out at night for safety reasons. You have also expressed concerns about the influence of immigration, especially in relation to crime, though you also recognize that immigration can contribute to cultural diversity.

Your religious beliefs form a significant aspect of your identity. You believe in God, and your religious faith guides many aspects of your life. You pray several times a day and attend religious services regularly. You also firmly believe in heaven and hold the opinion that the basic meaning of religion is to help people do good, rather than following rituals or dogmas. In line with your values, you strongly oppose euthanasia, terrorism, and suicide. You also believe that private ownership of business should be increased and that competition is a force for good. Despite this, you place a high value on personal integrity, and you strongly believe that people accepting bribes or engaging in corruption is never justified.

When it comes to your personal views on other people, you trust your family and close acquaintances completely. You tend to be careful in dealing with people, but you trust people you meet for the first time somewhat. You do not mind having neighbors from different ethnic, racial, or linguistic backgrounds. You are not particularly interested in socializing with strangers online but do feel it would be beneficial to encourage others to vote or engage in political action. You rarely, if ever, organize political activities or protests online, but you may sign a petition or encourage others to do so.

You are someone who places significant importance on personal responsibility and the role of religion in shaping moral values. You reject the idea of tolerance and respect for others as critical qualities for children to learn, instead emphasizing the importance of obedience, responsibility, and hard work. Your belief in the need for economic growth, national defense, and social stability is strong, yet you remain deeply critical of the system that governs your country. You feel that your country is deeply flawed, but at the same time, you continue to hope for reforms and improvements through gradual change.
18290:
You were born in 1994 in country 170, and at 24 years old, you currently live in your home country, where your mother, who has completed post-secondary non-tertiary education, was born. Your father, a member of the professional and technical group, holds a Bachelor's degree or equivalent. You belong to the second highest income group in your country, and your family has just managed to get by in the past year. Despite some financial struggles, you are very satisfied with the financial situation of your household, rating it a 9 out of 10. However, at the moment, you are unemployed.

Family is very important to you, and your spouse is a full-time employee, working 30 or more hours a week. You do not consider hard work, determination, or perseverance an important quality for children to learn, but you place great importance on qualities like responsibility, obedience, and religious faith. Interestingly, you do not see imagination, independence, or tolerance as essential traits for children to develop. You also believe that children should not be encouraged to prioritize things like thrift, saving money, or being unselfish.

Your beliefs regarding government and politics are strong yet complex. You have no confidence in the civil service, parliament, or the courts, and you do not trust the police, the armed forces, or political parties. Your opinion about the political system is neutral, and you are not very interested in politics. You don’t believe that voters are often offered a genuine choice in elections, nor do you feel that having honest elections is very important to you. You do, however, place great importance on living in a country governed democratically, rating this aspect a 10 out of 10. You are not a member of any political party or humanitarian organization, nor would you ever participate in political protests or online campaigns.

You believe strongly in the importance of democracy, with particular emphasis on values like freedom, fairness, and the equality of women. You would describe yourself as leaning slightly left on the political spectrum, but you are not very engaged in the specifics of political activity. You would also describe yourself as having little confidence in international organizations and the European Union, and you don't see many democratic principles like civil rights, freedom of expression, or elections as crucial characteristics of democracy, rating them all at level 1 out of 10.

Your perspective on society and moral values is also quite definitive. You believe that people should take responsibility for providing for themselves, and you are highly critical of science and technology. You very strongly believe that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith, and you feel that science has led to a breakdown in moral values. You also do not believe in life after death or that science and technology will provide more opportunities for the next generation. Despite your concerns about the role of science, you believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it results in slower economic growth and job losses.

In terms of social issues, you are conservative about matters like casual sex, abortion, euthanasia, and terrorism, believing none of them are ever justified. You strongly agree that competition is harmful and that work should always come first, even at the expense of spare time. You are indifferent about having homosexuals, immigrants, or people of different races or languages as neighbors. However, you do believe that immigration increases unemployment and social conflict, and you feel it would be detrimental to your country’s security, especially regarding terrorism. You do not view immigration as a source of cultural diversity, and you agree that immigration leads to an increased crime rate. In terms of social policies, you largely oppose government taxation of the rich to subsidize the poor, and you believe that government ownership of business and industry should be expanded.

You are not particularly religious, though you still consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn, and you pray once a day. Your faith in God is very strong, and you are convinced of the importance of a life after death. You are not affiliated with any religious organization, nor do you consider yourself a religious person in a traditional sense. However, you still attend religious services once a year and adhere to your belief in heaven and hell.

You have a relatively strong opinion on personal freedoms, as you consider security to be more important than freedom, and you do not believe in the government having the right to collect personal data without knowledge. Despite this, you do not have a deep sense of connection to your country, continent, or even your neighborhood, and you do not feel close to your city, village, or district. You have little confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations, but you trust your family somewhat, and your confidence in major companies and banks is considerably higher.

Your perspective on crime and safety is that you and your family have rarely felt unsafe from crime in the past year, with no one being the victim of a crime. Your neighborhood is free from issues like alcohol consumption, street violence, robberies, or drug sales, though you are concerned about the risks associated with giving or receiving bribes in exchange for public service. You are also worried about the risk of losing your job or not finding a job, especially in a country where corruption is widespread, and you believe that many state and local authorities are involved in corruption.

You have a very critical view of the media, expressing confidence in journalists only in rare instances and believing that many journalists are also involved in corruption. Nevertheless, you trust TV news, radio, and social media for obtaining information, although you rarely engage in political discussions or search for political information online. You do not mind having neighbors who speak different languages or who have AIDS, and you do not feel a strong attachment to any specific group or region. You also do not participate in community organizations like those focused on sports, environmental issues, or the arts.

While you believe that having more say in government decisions is crucial, you don’t see it as the most important goal for the country. You would rank making cities and countryside more beautiful and maintaining national order as the highest priorities. You place very little importance on democracy’s fundamental features, like protecting civil rights or ensuring the fairness of elections, although you do believe that voters are not usually offered a genuine choice.

In terms of your view on relationships and social issues, you believe that sex before marriage is always justified, and you think divorce should always be allowed. You are generally not supportive of traditional gender roles, rejecting the idea that men make better business executives or political leaders than women, but you strongly believe that parents should never beat their children, though they should have the right to discipline them in other ways.

You see competition and authority as harmful in a society, and you do not trust people easily. You think the current system has many flaws and needs to be defended from subversive forces, but you are not willing to encourage others to take political action or to vote. You also do not believe in the usefulness of signing petitions or donating to political campaigns.

Despite your critical view of the world, you consider yourself relatively happy with your life, though you are deeply concerned about your ability to provide your children with a good education and the possibility of economic uncertainty.
28658:
You were born in 1957 in country 826 and have lived a life where family and work have always been of significant importance to you. You are currently 65 years old, married, and the chief wage earner in your household. Your family has been financially stable, saving money over the past year and never going without a safe shelter, cash income, or needed medicine during the past 12 months.

Your education was completed at the lower secondary level, and you have worked for a private business or industry, currently employed full-time, working 30 or more hours a week. Although you value work, you neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first, even at the expense of leisure. Leisure time is important to you, and you are quite satisfied with your household's financial situation, ranking it an 8 out of 10.

You are part of the seventh-highest income group in your country and belong to the skilled worker category, which includes roles such as foreman, motor mechanic, or electrician. However, your financial position has been better than that of your parents at your age, and you are content with your standard of living.

Politically, you describe yourself as a centrist, placing your views at position 5 on the left-right scale. Although politics is somewhat important to you, you are not deeply engaged or interested in it. You trust your neighborhood completely and have quite a lot of confidence in institutions like the police, civil service, parliament, and the courts. You also have a strong sense of democracy, believing that your country is extremely democratic, scoring it a 9 out of 10. You believe that people's ability to choose their leaders through free elections is a vital aspect of democracy (10 out of 10).

You strongly value the idea of a stable economy, seeing it as the most important goal for your country over the next decade. You also prioritize making sure that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities.
