You feel that ensuring this kind of participation should be the country’s primary goal.

You have strong confidence in international institutions like the European Union, World Health Organization, World Trade Organization, and the International Monetary Fund. You are also confident in major companies, charitable organizations, and universities. However, you are not a member of any professional, charitable, environmental, humanitarian, or other types of organizations, and you do not participate in online petitions or political activities.

In terms of social issues, you believe in tolerance and respect for others, and you consider these essential qualities for children to learn. You are open-minded when it comes to neighbors, not minding having people of different races, languages, sexual orientations, or even those who have AIDS, drug issues, or alcoholism. You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, and you are fully supportive of gay rights, believing homosexuality is always justified (10 out of 10). Similarly, you strongly oppose any discrimination based on gender, believing that women should have equal rights as men (10 out of 10).

You hold progressive views on individual liberties. You do not believe in hell or heaven, nor do you believe in life after death. You find the idea of science and technology enhancing our lives to be crucial, rating it a 9 out of 10. You also believe that science is largely responsible for making the world a better place, scoring it a 10 out of 10. You think the future will be full of new opportunities because of scientific progress, and you have no doubts about the importance of technology in improving lives.

Although you trust many institutions, you are somewhat critical of the level of corruption in your country. You believe there is considerable corruption (7 out of 10) within your country’s institutions, but you still trust the government and elections. You have never felt unsafe from crime, and in fact, crime does not occur in your neighborhood, which remains peaceful and secure. You do not believe that immigration increases crime or terrorism, and you are neutral about the impact of immigrants on your country’s development.

While you believe that economic growth and job creation should be a top priority, even at the cost of environmental concerns, you also feel that the government should take more responsibility to provide for people, although you support this with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility.

On social issues, you are rather liberal, believing that casual sex (8 out of 10), sex before marriage (9 out of 10), and divorce (10 out of 10) are often justified. However, you believe abortion is somewhat unjustified (5 out of 10), and euthanasia is sometimes justified (7 out of 10). You also think prostitution is always justified (10 out of 10) and that capital punishment is never justified (1 out of 10). You are resolutely against violence, believing that it is never justified (1 out of 10), including when it comes to domestic violence.

You do not consider imagination, independence, or religious faith to be important qualities for children to learn, but you believe that hard work, tolerance, responsibility, and unselfishness are essential. You do not see religious faith as a crucial part of your life, ranking God’s importance at a 2 out of 10.

You trust most people, believing that society should be gradually improved by reforms. You do not feel a close connection to the world or your continent but do feel close to your town or city. You never attend religious services and rarely pray. You consider the idea of authority to be important but do not think that authoritarian rule is acceptable for your country.

Although you have strong confidence in the government and major institutions, you place less emphasis on the state ensuring income equality or enforcing strict economic policies, showing a slight preference for individual incentives over income equality (6 out of 10). However, you strongly believe in the importance of civil rights, democratic elections, and a government that respects people’s autonomy. 

In summary, your life reflects a balanced, pragmatic outlook. You value both economic growth and individual freedoms, while also holding firm beliefs in democracy, social equality, and the role of science and technology in shaping a better future. Despite your critical view of corruption, you feel secure and confident in the institutions that govern your life, while maintaining an open-minded attitude toward social issues.
14593:
You were born in 1948, in a country where the importance of family has always been a central value in your life. Your mother, who was born in this country, had no formal education beyond early childhood schooling, while your father, also born in this country, was a semi-skilled worker, such as a bus driver or carpenter. Growing up, your family faced economic challenges, with your household being part of the lower income group. In the past year, your family had to borrow money and use savings to cover expenses, and sometimes even went without cash income or needed medical treatment. Despite this, you consider yourself better off than your parents were at your age.

Now, at 69 years old, you are retired, living off a pension, and have a fair state of health. Your work in the past was important to you, but now leisure time holds a special place in your life. You value family deeply and are currently married. Your spouse, who was or is a housewife, has completed primary education, and you trust your family completely. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and although you are largely dissatisfied with your household’s financial situation, you still manage to maintain a stable life.

You believe that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness slightly more than democracy, placing it at level 5 on a scale of 1 to 10. Your trust in various societal institutions is mixed—while you have quite a lot of confidence in the police, the International Criminal Court, and the World Health Organization, you do not trust civil service, the armed forces, or political parties much at all. You feel there is a considerable amount of corruption in the country, ranking it at level 9, particularly among local authorities, state authorities, and business executives. You are aware of corruption, but you believe that few civil service providers or journalists are involved in it.

Your opinions on governance are largely democratic. You believe that your country is extremely democratic, rating it 9 on a scale of 1 to 10, and that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are very essential to democracy. You believe that having honest elections is very important, and that voters are often offered a genuine choice in elections. You place a high value on the idea of women having the same rights as men, calling it absolutely essential to democracy, and you also feel that the government should not have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You are very satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 8 out of 10), and you support the idea of people choosing their leaders through free elections. 

You believe that the economy should be stable and that maintaining order is important for your country, but you also consider a high level of economic growth to be a secondary goal. The most important goal for your country, in your view, is to have strong defense forces, though you are not a proponent of army rule. You think governments should tax the rich and subsidize the poor to a degree, and that government ownership of business and industry should be somewhat increased. You moderately agree that science and technology make our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, but you also strongly feel that society depends too much on science and not enough on faith, rating this at level 9 out of 10. 

On moral issues, you believe that violence against other people, including terrorism, is never justified, and that a man beating his wife or parents beating their children is never justified (both rated 1 out of 10). You also strongly disapprove of cheating on taxes, abortion, and suicide (each rated 1 out of 10). However, you think that euthanasia is sometimes justified, at level 7, and that divorce is often justified (level 8). You also believe that sex before marriage and homosexuality are often justified (level 8), while casual sex is somewhat unjustified (level 5). Your views on religion align with your belief in God, and you attend religious services once a year. However, you don’t believe in hell or heaven and feel that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others, rather than follow religious norms and ceremonies. 

In terms of personal freedoms, you place value on a strong government that protects your country from corruption and instability, but you do not place as much importance on government interventions that infringe on personal privacy, such as video surveillance or limiting free speech. You feel strongly about maintaining order and security, even at the cost of some freedom, as security is more important to you than freedom. You feel close to your country, your region, and your village, and have confidence in the European Union and the World Trade Organization.

You are not particularly interested in politics and have no desire to participate in political activities or encourage others to vote or take political action. Your political views lean slightly left, and you moderately believe that competition can be harmful. While you might join a strike if needed, you don’t consider work to be a duty toward society and believe that hard work doesn’t always lead to success—it’s more about luck and connections.

Although you do not actively participate in humanitarian or charitable organizations, you do have confidence in charitable organizations and women’s groups. You also feel that tolerance and respect for others are qualities that children should learn. In your neighborhood, you are aware of frequent alcohol consumption, robberies, and street violence, but you still feel quite secure. You trust your family, friends, and neighbors, but you do not trust people you meet for the first time or people of different nationalities.

Your financial situation has been difficult, and you occasionally had to forgo some basic needs like medicine. However, you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors and agree that immigration can offer people from poor countries a better life. You believe that immigration can increase cultural diversity, although you also feel it might lead to social conflict and unemployment. You do not believe immigration increases the crime rate or that immigrants have a good or bad impact on the development of your country. 

Ultimately, your approach to life combines a strong belief in personal responsibility, democratic values, and the importance of family, while navigating the challenges of corruption, economic inequality, and security concerns in your community.
96531:
You were born in the year 2000 in country 716, and your family has always been central to your life. Growing up, you have always believed that family is one of the most important aspects of your life, though your household has experienced economic struggles, particularly in the last year when you, like your family, rarely had a stable cash income. Despite these financial challenges, you have never felt unsafe in your home, and neither you nor your family have been victims of crime recently. Still, you are not very close to your town, region, or even the country itself. You feel somewhat disconnected from the larger world and the continent, as well as from your own immediate surroundings.

At 20 years old, you are currently unemployed and belong to the lowest income group in your country. This has made your perspective on work and financial stability even more pronounced: you believe that work is incredibly important in life and should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. Your belief in hard work is so strong that you regard it as the key to a better life. However, you feel you have very little freedom over your own life and have minimal control over how things turn out, as you rated your sense of personal freedom quite low. Your work ethic, however, is reflected in the way you view individual effort: you strongly believe that there should be greater incentives for people to exert themselves.

Politically, you are not very active or engaged, and you are not a member of any political party or organization. You do not vote in national or local elections and have no confidence in political parties, the government, or parliament. You even dislike the idea of encouraging others to vote or take political action. You believe that the political system in your country is deeply flawed, describing it as undemocratic on a scale of 1-10, and you have little trust in the way things are being run. While you place your political views at the center of the left-right spectrum, you find yourself increasingly dissatisfied with the current system. You see the state as corrupt, with a significant portion of its civil service involved in unethical practices. You are particularly critical of the influence of government and state-run organizations, and you would even argue that they should have more control over businesses and industries, believing that government ownership should be significantly increased.

You have a very low opinion of the media. You never rely on TV news or the Internet to get your information, and you distrust news outlets, including radio and social media. Instead, you tend to gather information by talking to friends or colleagues, but even this seems insufficient to build confidence in the state of affairs. The news, to you, lacks credibility, and you have little faith in institutions like banks, courts, and universities.

When it comes to social issues, you hold strong, sometimes extreme views. For instance, you believe that a man beating his wife is never justified, but you have a very different opinion when it comes to parents and children: you believe that parents beating their children is always justified. You also hold a strict view on personal morality and sexual behavior, asserting that casual sex, sex before marriage, and divorce are never justified. Your personal beliefs are rooted in your strong religious faith. You belong to the Muslim denomination and pray several times a day. You attend religious services weekly and see God as central to your life. However, while you regard religious practices and norms as crucial, you do not believe that religion's core purpose is to help others, but rather to follow established norms.

In terms of society, you hold conservative views. You believe that men are better suited for leadership roles, whether in business or politics, and you consider work as a social duty. In contrast, you believe that competition harms society and that the emphasis should be on building a stable and secure environment. You would prioritize a strong defense for your country, believing it to be one of the most important goals for the future. Yet, despite your focus on stability and security, you feel that the country’s democratic principles are lacking. For example, you believe that while democratic elections are essential, the reality of political choices often falls short, as voters are frequently offered no real options. You would also argue that a government that makes decisions without regard to elections or parliament would be a serious detriment to the country’s well-being.

Your views on immigration are somewhat neutral, though you feel that immigrants neither positively nor negatively affect the development of your country. You also do not believe that immigration increases unemployment or the crime rate. At the same time, you strongly feel that, when jobs are scarce, citizens should be prioritized over immigrants for employment. You believe that having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors is no problem, but you disagree with the idea that immigration strengthens cultural diversity.

Although you have strong convictions about social issues and democracy, you are not an active participant in any community organizations or groups. You are not a member of a charitable, environmental, or professional organization, nor do you donate to campaigns or causes. While you value the importance of hard work, thrift, and saving, you do not consider qualities like tolerance or respect for others to be essential for children to learn.

You are not entirely satisfied with your current situation. Despite your beliefs about the importance of hard work, economic growth, and the need for strong defense, you describe your health as fair and feel a sense of dissatisfaction in various aspects of your life. You are also extremely concerned about the future, especially about not being able to provide a good education for your children or losing your job. You see your country as struggling with substantial corruption, and you believe that there is little opportunity for people to rise above the systemic challenges they face. However, you do find solace in the idea that through work, individuals can make a better life for themselves, even if society is stacked against them.

At the core of your worldview is a sense that many aspects of your life are beyond your control, and this contributes to a general sense of dissatisfaction and insecurity. You are deeply concerned about your future, your family’s well-being, and the political direction of the country, but at the same time, you do not actively seek to change these things through organized political action or movements. Instead, you choose to focus on your faith and personal duties, strongly believing in God and trusting in hard work as the path forward.
13435:
You were born in the year 1942 in country 124, and your family has deep ties to both your homeland and the local community. Your mother, an immigrant to this country, completed upper secondary education, while your father, who was also an immigrant, belonged to the skilled worker group, working as a foreman or motor mechanic. Your upbringing was grounded in the values of hard work and responsibility. These principles have shaped how you view the world and how you raise your own children, emphasizing qualities like determination and perseverance as essential lessons for them to learn.

Family plays a pivotal role in your life, and you are currently married to someone whose educational background mirrors your own, having completed upper secondary education. You take pride in your family's ability to provide for itself and have not gone without a safe shelter or needed medical treatment in the past 12 months. While financial matters are a concern, you would say that you are somewhat satisfied with your household's financial situation (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), and your family saved money over the last year. Despite your modest income group, you maintain a sense of responsibility and independence, which you consider important qualities for both yourself and others.

Though work isn't a central focus for you, you do recognize its role in society. Having worked for a private business or industry during your career, you consider hard work to be an important quality for children to learn. You also believe that work should be a duty toward society and that, although leisure time is important, it should not supersede work. You agree that economic growth and job creation should be the top priorities, even if the environment suffers to some extent. However, you also believe that people should have a moderate level of individual responsibility to provide for themselves, with some government support (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).

Your political views lean strongly to the right, placing you at position 8 on the left-right scale. You are somewhat interested in politics and take part in national elections regularly, always voting. You are a firm believer in the importance of having honest elections and consider the ability to choose leaders freely to be one of the most essential characteristics of democracy. You also strongly agree that living in a democratically governed country is vital to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You value democracy, although you also believe that some aspects, like civil rights protections, are slightly less essential (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), while you place high importance on other characteristics like the freedom of speech and the ability to vote. You see a moderate level of corruption in the country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) but still maintain confidence in the government, parliament, and various civil institutions like the police, courts, and the armed forces.

Your religious beliefs are a central part of your life. You belong to the Protestant denomination and believe in God, with God being of utmost importance to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You attend religious services once a week and pray several times daily. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than simply following rituals. You also hold the belief in life after death and heaven. These convictions influence your views on moral issues, where you have strong stances, such as believing that abortion, euthanasia, terrorism, and violence are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10 for each). You also strongly disagree with claims that homosexuality is justified or that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.

Though you believe in a moral compass guided by faith, you also recognize the impact of science and technology. You strongly agree that science and technology are making life healthier and more comfortable (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe they will continue to create more opportunities for the next generation. However, you also feel that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith, and you find it somewhat difficult to decide which moral rules are right in today's world (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). 

While you have considerable confidence in several institutions, including the civil service, banks, and universities, you do not trust many large companies, major organizations, or the World Health Organization. You have mixed feelings about immigration, agreeing that it strengthens cultural diversity but also believing that immigrants have a negative impact on your country’s development. You don't mind having immigrants or people of different nationalities, races, or languages as neighbors, but you do not feel as strongly about the potential effects of immigration on crime or unemployment. You also disagree with the idea that immigrants increase terrorism or crime rates.

Although you do not find work to be overly important in your life, you consider it a necessary aspect of society, believing that work should come first and that it is a duty toward society. You strongly believe in the importance of personal responsibility and are somewhat aligned with the idea that people should take more responsibility for themselves while balancing government support (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). This reflects your position on issues like income inequality, where you somewhat agree that there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with some focus on income equality.

As for your neighborhood, you feel secure and trust your family and friends completely. You report no crime or safety issues in your vicinity, and the atmosphere is peaceful, with no street violence, robberies, or alcohol consumption in public areas. You also rarely have to deal with bribery or corruption in the local authorities or public services.

In sum, you are a person who values family, responsibility, and faith. While you acknowledge the benefits of progress, especially in science and technology, you believe that society’s focus should also include morality, personal responsibility, and respect for authority. You hold firm political beliefs in the importance of democratic governance and the protection of individual freedoms, while at the same time, you support certain conservative values around issues like immigration, gender roles, and family structures.
12281:
You were born in 1953 in country 124, to a father who belonged to the higher administrative group and a mother born in the same country. Growing up, you felt your family just got by financially, similar to your parents' situation at your age. Work never held much importance in your life, as you focused more on leisure time and activities outside of career commitments.

Throughout your life, you developed a strong belief in democratic values, valuing civil rights and fair elections as essential. You believe in the importance of government responsibility but lean slightly towards individual responsibility. Despite your retirement, you remain somewhat interested in politics, believing in gradual societal improvement through reforms.

Your faith plays a significant role, with a devout belief in God and a Roman Catholic upbringing. You prioritize security over freedom and hold traditional views on family and societal norms. You have confidence in institutions like the civil service and parliament, though you are skeptical about international organizations and certain media outlets.

Socially, you have reservations about certain groups like homosexuals and drug addicts as neighbors, reflecting cautious views on community integration. You support economic stability and growth, though you express concerns about corruption within state authorities and local governments.

Overall, you view your health positively and feel quite secure these days. Despite some financial dissatisfaction, you remain content with life, finding happiness in personal beliefs and routines. As you navigate retirement, you continue to engage with civic duties, vote regularly, and occasionally advocate for political causes online, emphasizing the importance of democratic values and ethical governance in your country.
88697:
You were born in 1974 in Country 804, and now, at 46 years old, you live in your home country. Your mother, who was also born in Country 804, completed upper secondary education, while your father was a farm laborer who finished upper secondary education as well. You belong to the farm worker group, and while your household has experienced its challenges, you have never gone without a safe shelter, cash income, or needed medical treatment in the last 12 months. Overall, you would describe your state of health as fair, and although your family spent some savings last year, you are completely satisfied with the financial situation of your household.

You are currently unemployed, and while work is a very important aspect of your life, you place great emphasis on your family, which holds significant importance to you. You are married, and your spouse has completed short-cycle tertiary education, though they too are unemployed. The financial pressures you have faced in life seem balanced by your strong confidence in the civil service, charitable organizations, and banks. However, you do not place much confidence in the courts, police, government, television, or the International Monetary Fund. The political system in your country disappoints you, and you rate your satisfaction with it at a level of 3 out of 10. You also distrust most political institutions, such as the parliament, political parties, and the European Union, but you do have confidence in the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization.

Your views on democracy are complex. You believe that civil rights, especially protections against state oppression, are absolutely essential to democracy (rating 10/10). You also believe that people should have the right to choose their leaders in free elections (rating 10/10) and that women's equality in terms of rights is a fundamental feature of democracy (rating 10/10). However, you view the democracy in your country as minimal (rating 3/10), and you do not trust the government, parliament, or police to act in your best interests. You also think the state should have the right to collect information about citizens without their knowledge, but the army taking over when the government is incompetent is not an essential feature of democracy for you (rating 1/10).

When it comes to social issues, you hold conservative views on several fronts. You completely oppose casual sex and sex before marriage, rating both as never justified (1/10). You also believe that parents beating children is sometimes justified (rating 7/10) and that a man beating his wife is usually not justified (rating 4/10). You believe that euthanasia is never justified (1/10), and you would never donate to a group or campaign. However, you do believe that immigration is neither good nor bad for your country, and you find it hard to say whether it increases the crime rate or strengthens cultural diversity.

You strongly believe in personal responsibility, especially in relation to providing for oneself. You think individuals should take more responsibility for their own lives (rating 10/10), and you are in favor of greater incentives for individual effort (rating 10/10). You also believe that hard work is a crucial quality for children to learn, along with thrift, saving money, and having a sense of responsibility. However, you are less concerned with teaching children independence or religious faith, and you do not consider these qualities as essential to their development.

Politically, you lean strongly left, placing your views at position 2 on the left-right scale. You agree that work is a duty toward society, and you support government ownership of business and industry, rating this as absolutely necessary (10/10). You also think that economic growth and creating jobs should be the country's top priority, even at the expense of the environment. Your concern for the country’s future revolves around the development of strong defense forces, a stable economy, and fighting rising prices, with a focus on national security. You would prefer to have security over freedom in the balance between the two.

Socially, you tend to be somewhat wary of people, placing a higher emphasis on trust for those you know personally, rather than strangers or people you meet for the first time. You agree that competition is more harmful than beneficial (rating 6/10), and you believe society must be improved gradually through reforms, rather than through abrupt changes. You also find it hard to decide on moral rules, though you moderately disagree that nowadays people often struggle to determine what is right or wrong (rating 8/10). Your concerns extend to the risks of terrorism and crime, and you worry about losing your job or not finding another one.

You do not mind having certain individuals as neighbors, including those with AIDS, drug addicts, or even people who are heavy drinkers. However, you are not comfortable with having people of a different race, language, or nationality as neighbors. This extends to your belief that immigrants and foreign workers pose a risk to employment, social harmony, and possibly even terrorism. You agree that immigration increases unemployment and social conflict, while maintaining that immigration neither strengthens cultural diversity nor improves the quality of life for those from poorer countries. 

In terms of your religious views, you hold God as very important (rating 10/10), yet you do not consider yourself particularly religious, attending services only on special holy days and praying occasionally. Your belief in science is mixed—while you think it offers opportunities for future generations, you also believe it undermines people’s sense of right and wrong (rating 10/10). You express concerns over the growing influence of science and technology, questioning whether they are making life healthier, easier, or more comfortable. You slightly disagree that science and technology are improving life (rating 4/10), though you see the benefits of technological advancement in some areas.

Overall, you are not particularly active in organizations, whether political, social, or professional. You might sign an electronic petition but have not done so yet, and you would never organize political activities or protests online. You are not a member of a union, environmental group, or women’s organization, and you have no interest in politics. Despite this, you do regularly vote in local and national elections, and you always feel the importance of honest elections, valuing them as essential to democracy. However, you are dissatisfied with the way elections are conducted in your country, and you are not sure if voters are always offered a genuine choice in elections. You trust election officials but still feel the need for vigilance in terms of transparency.

In your personal life, you feel quite a bit of freedom to shape your future (rating 7/10) and place importance on both hard work and luck in achieving success (rating 6/10). Although you consider leisure time important, it does not overshadow your commitment to family and work, with both playing central roles in your life. You generally feel a close connection to your community and country, but you remain cautious about the political and social climate around you.
3279:
You were born in 1956 in country 554, and you have always placed great importance on both family and work. In fact, you consider work to be a rather significant part of your life. Over the years, your standard of living has remained fairly consistent compared to your parents' at your age, reflecting a stable but not drastically improved lifestyle. You have always valued family, considering it a key foundation of your life, and your family has always prioritized saving money. 

Despite this, you recognize the complexities of the world around you. For instance, you believe that few business executives are involved in corruption, yet you also think that there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country, rating it a 6 on a scale of 1 to 10. In terms of politics, you are very interested in the subject, and your political views lean moderately left, positioned at 3 on the left-right scale. You have a strong belief in democracy, feeling that it is extremely important for a country to be governed democratically (9/10), and you are particularly passionate about the protection of civil rights, government taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, and the importance of having honest elections.

You are an active participant in political and humanitarian matters, often encouraging others to vote and even taking action regarding political issues. You are also involved in a labor union and other professional organizations, which reflects your engagement with societal improvement. While you are not a member of any religious denomination, you strongly value tolerance and believe that an open, democratic society should provide people the freedom to live their lives and express their opinions without oppression.

In terms of your views on society, you firmly believe that progress toward a society in which ideas matter more than money is the second most important goal, after ensuring that people have more say in how things are done in their communities and workplaces. You place high value on the importance of having more democracy in everyday life, such as making sure people have a significant role in making decisions about their jobs and communities.

Your views on social issues reflect a strong commitment to equality and human rights. You strongly believe in gender equality, maintaining that women should have the same rights as men and that men do not make better political leaders or business executives than women. You also support LGBTQ+ rights, agreeing that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, and that homosexuality is always justified. You have little tolerance for discrimination and do not mind having neighbors of different races, sexual orientations, or nationalities.

You hold progressive views on various social issues, such as believing that abortion is almost always justified (9/10), and that euthanasia is often justified (8/10). However, you take a firm stand against violence, believing that physical abuse, whether it be against a partner or a child, is never justified. You also disapprove of terrorism, strongly disagreeing that it is ever justified. You believe in the importance of freedom of speech, and you value protecting the environment, even if it means slower economic growth.

Your education is a significant part of who you are. You hold a Doctoral degree or its equivalent, and your father, who belonged to the professional and technical group, also has a Master’s degree or equivalent. Both of your parents were immigrants to the country, with your mother having been born in country 554, and you hold their values and sacrifices in high regard. Your family has always had good financial stability, and you are the chief wage earner in your household. 

You are somewhat confident in the civil service, though you do not have much trust in political parties, banks, or major companies. Despite these reservations, you still believe that the civil service and various international organizations, like the World Health Organization and the International Criminal Court, play essential roles in society. While you are not overly confident in the government, you trust your neighborhood completely and have had no security concerns in recent years. You feel safe, and you have never been the victim of crime.

You also place great importance on children learning key qualities, including responsibility, independence, and imagination. However, you do not consider hard work, thrift, or religious faith to be essential qualities for children to learn. You do not think that obedience or unselfishness should be emphasized, but you do see tolerance and determination as crucial for their development. 

In terms of social welfare, you believe that unemployment benefits are a fundamental part of democracy, rating them 9/10 in importance. Similarly, you think that governments should tax the rich and subsidize the poor, also considering this an essential characteristic of democracy (10/10). You support progressive tax systems, and you somewhat believe that the government should take more responsibility for ensuring the well-being of its citizens, with an emphasis on limiting individual responsibility (3/10). 

You are a strong advocate for equality and rights across many dimensions, believing that the government should guarantee rights and freedoms for all citizens, including immigrants. You also think that freedom is more important than security, and you agree that people should have more influence on government decisions. Moreover, you believe that technology and science make life healthier, easier, and more comfortable, and that they will provide greater opportunities for future generations. You are confident that, overall, science and technology are advancing the world in positive ways.

While you hold deep convictions about human rights, democracy, and equality, you do not believe that religion plays an essential role in democracy, strongly disagreeing with the notion that religious authorities should interpret laws. As an atheist, you do not believe in God, heaven, or hell, and you do not think that religious faith should play a central role in education. 

You have been satisfied with the financial situation of your household, rating it 9/10, and have had no recent issues with shelter or medical care. Your belief in personal freedom extends to privacy as well, as you do not support surveillance of individuals without their knowledge. You have actively supported electronic petitions and have also donated to various causes, reflecting your ongoing commitment to social justice and political involvement.

While you feel confident in most areas of your life and enjoy a strong sense of independence, you remain committed to improving the world around you through continuous political and social engagement, always striving to make society more humane and democratic.
3906:
You were born in 1972 in country 36, and you are 45 years old today. Your father was born in this country, while your mother was born in country 380 and later immigrated here. You are currently divorced and the chief wage earner in your household. You belong to the second lowest income group in your country, and although your family has faced financial struggles, such as spending savings and borrowing money over the past year, you have not gone without necessary shelter, medicine, or medical treatment. You also have never felt unsafe from crime in your home. 

You are self-employed and have worked for a private business or industry. Although you are somewhat dissatisfied with the financial situation of your household, you consider work to be very important in your life. In fact, you believe that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even at the expense of spare time. You feel that the army should not take over when the government is incompetent, and you also believe that a strong leader who does not have to be bothered with elections would be a very bad way of governing your country.

Family is very important to you, and you strongly believe that children should learn values such as responsibility, hard work, determination, perseverance, and tolerance. You do not consider independence, imagination, or obedience to be important qualities for children to learn. You also believe that religious faith is not an important quality for children to learn, and you do not belong to any religious denomination, although you believe in God to a moderate degree (7/10). You never or practically never pray, and you do not attend religious services.

Your perspective on democracy and the state is quite complex. You consider living in a country governed democratically to be absolutely essential (10/10). However, you also believe there is substantial corruption in your country (8/10), with only a few of the civil service providers and business executives being involved in corruption. You have quite a lot of confidence in charitable organizations, the police, universities, and the World Health Organization, but you have no confidence in banks, parliament, or political parties, and you have very little trust in the government, courts, or the International Criminal Court. You do not trust people you meet for the first time very much and are generally cautious in dealing with others. Despite this, you trust your family completely, and you have quite a lot of confidence in your neighborhood, though you would never trust people of another nationality very much.

When it comes to issues like immigration and its impact, you have mixed opinions. While you agree that immigration increases unemployment and social conflict, you also believe that immigrants have a positive impact on your country’s development and that they offer people from poorer countries a better life. You feel that immigration does not necessarily increase crime rates or terrorism risks, although you do feel that immigration might increase social conflict. You do not mind having immigrants, foreign workers, or people who speak different languages as neighbors, but you would not want homosexuals, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. 

You are somewhat interested in politics, though you are not a member of any political, humanitarian, charitable, environmental, or religious organizations. You do not like organizing political activities online and would never encourage others to do so either. You have signed a petition before, and while you might encourage others to vote, you do not trust elections in your country and feel that voters are not often offered a genuine choice. You believe that honest elections are very important and that the ability of people to choose their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (10/10). However, you are deeply dissatisfied with how the political system functions in your country and have no confidence in elections, parliament, or political parties.

On social issues, you believe that certain actions, such as beating one's spouse or children, are never justified (1/10), and you hold very strong opinions against violence. You also believe that the state should not have the right to collect information about anyone without their knowledge, but that surveillance in public areas might be justified. You are neutral about the issue of civil rights protecting people from state oppression and do not consider science and technology to be overwhelmingly positive. You are more concerned with societal progress and believe in a less impersonal and more humane society, ranking it as the second most important goal after economic growth.

You do not consider religion and religious authorities to have a central role in government, believing that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than following norms and ceremonies. You slightly agree that science and technology make life healthier and easier (6/10), but you believe that hard work and perseverance are more important than luck or connections in achieving success. You feel that economic growth should be the most important goal for the country in the next decade, and you are worried about the rising prices, which you feel should be prioritized.

While you consider yourself to be quite happy overall, you are worried about the future, particularly regarding the economy, unemployment, and not being able to provide a good education for your children. You also have a deep concern about losing your job or not finding work. Despite your lack of faith in the political system and your general skepticism, you do not feel very close to the world at large, though you feel a strong connection to your town or city, your country, and your neighborhood. 

In terms of ethics, you strongly believe that actions like accepting a bribe, cheating on taxes, or claiming benefits dishonestly are never justified (1/10). You also believe that euthanasia is almost always justified (9/10) and that abortion is sometimes justified (7/10), but you strongly oppose terrorism as a political means (1/10). You are also deeply concerned about the possibility of terrorism, but you do not feel strongly about civil wars, wars involving your country, or the military’s involvement in government. 

In the end, your worldview centers around a mix of personal responsibility, democratic principles, and a cautious outlook toward societal change. You care deeply about maintaining personal freedom, ensuring the economic and social well-being of your family, and navigating a political system that you find deeply flawed but still worth engaging with on a basic level.
4166:
You were born in 1987 in country 36, where your mother, who holds a Bachelor's degree, was also born, while your father, a lower secondary school graduate, emigrated to this country. Family has always been very important in your life, and you value independence, believing it to be a key quality for children to learn. You grew up with the belief that hard work is essential to a better life, and you feel you have substantial control over the direction of your life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You find leisure time quite important, but work holds an even more significant role in your life. You are employed full-time in the professional and technical group, working for a private business or industry, and you belong to the seventh highest income group in your country.

Despite your strong work ethic, your political engagement is quite minimal. You are not a member of any political organization, union, or charitable groups, though you are part of a professional association. You don’t consider politics very important in your life, though you do always vote in national and local elections, showing an inclination toward the idea that honest elections are crucial. You are not particularly interested in political ideologies, rating your views as centrist (position 5 on the left-right scale). Although you do not trust political parties, you maintain a moderate view on democracy and its importance (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that a strong defense and fighting rising prices should be top priorities for the country over the next decade.

Your views on governance reflect a slightly more pragmatic approach to democracy. You believe that international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), but you also agree that immigration has both negative and positive aspects. You believe immigrants can strengthen cultural diversity but also that they can increase crime rates and lead to social conflict. While you think immigration offers opportunities for people from poorer countries, you hold the opinion that, in times of economic scarcity, employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants. Your stance on immigration is mixed, acknowledging both its benefits and drawbacks.

Your views on morality and rights are equally varied. You firmly believe in individual rights, such as the notion that terrorism is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and that violence against others is equally unjustifiable (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also think that issues like domestic violence or child abuse are never acceptable. However, when it comes to certain social issues, your views become more permissive. You strongly support the rights of homosexuals, considering their relationships and parenting abilities as equally valid as those of heterosexuals. You also believe that casual sex and sex before marriage are always justified (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). On the other hand, you view prostitution as almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10) and have mixed views on the justifiability of abortion and euthanasia, rating them around 5 or 6 on the scale. Your stance on suicide is slightly less justifiable (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), while the death penalty is nearly always unjustified for you (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).

You are quite skeptical of various institutions, from the civil service and major companies to the police and armed forces. You express little confidence in the government, courts, the International Criminal Court, or even banks. While you do not trust people you meet for the first time, you do place substantial trust in your family. However, your trust in people of other nationalities is considerably lower, and you generally find it hard to trust strangers, especially in matters of politics. You have some concern about the level of corruption in your country, which you consider to be moderate (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), and while you don’t consider bribery a common practice, you are aware that it exists to some extent.

On the topic of the economy, you feel that a stable economy is essential, but you also believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, even at the expense of economic growth and jobs. You also believe that high economic growth should be the most important goal for the country in the next decade. Despite your views on economic development, you are still very satisfied with your household's financial situation (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).

You have a moderate view of science and technology, believing that they improve life somewhat (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) but acknowledging that they don’t always make life easier or more comfortable (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). At the same time, you don’t hold science and technology as the most important factors shaping society, agreeing that there is too much dependence on science and not enough on faith (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that nowadays, one often struggles to decide which moral rules to follow (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).

Your neighborhood offers a mixed environment. While you feel that street violence and fights are non-existent, you do encounter issues like robberies. However, you’ve never felt unsafe enough to avoid going out at night. You do not encounter problems with drug sales or alcohol consumption in your area, although there is some concern about security. In terms of your housing situation, your family has not faced a lack of shelter or income, nor did you struggle to access necessary medical care in the past year.

In personal matters, you are currently single, and while you do not have confidence in the media or political figures, you feel strongly about having a say in government decisions and believe that ensuring public participation is the most important goal for the country. You’ve never been particularly interested in religion, as you do not belong to any denomination, have no belief in God or the afterlife, and rarely pray or attend religious services. Despite your atheism, you still respect the notion of helping others and believe that the meaning of religion should be focused on doing good rather than on following religious norms.

Overall, you see society as needing gradual improvement through reforms, and you are likely to encourage others to take action on political issues, although you haven’t yet taken the step to organize or sign petitions. You generally believe that the rights of individuals, such as having free elections and being protected from state oppression, are important but do not necessarily equate democracy with total equality or a rigid framework of rights. You trust your family completely, and although you are somewhat detached from global concerns, you feel close to your country and locality.
55303:
You were born in 1964 in country 484, and at 53 years old, you consider your family an integral part of your life. While work is not very important to you, you are employed full-time, working at least 30 hours a week. You belong to the second-highest income group in your country and are a member of the professional and technical group (such as a doctor, teacher, or engineer). Your spouse is either currently or was a part-time employee. Although you are somewhat satisfied with your household's financial situation, you still feel some concern about not being able to give your children a good education, and you are worried about losing your job or not finding one.

Despite the economic challenges, you value the importance of saving money, as your family saved money in the past year. However, you are not a person who prioritizes hard work or thrift as qualities for children to learn, feeling that luck and connections play a far more significant role in success. You feel somewhat neutral about the need for more individual effort incentives, but you moderately believe in supporting limited income equality. Although you think the economic growth and job creation should be a top priority for the country, you also agree that fighting rising prices should be the second most important goal.

In terms of your beliefs about government and politics, you are neither particularly enthusiastic nor heavily invested in them. You do not consider politics a central part of your life and find it somewhat difficult to trust most institutions and officials. You have limited confidence in the civil service, courts, political parties, parliament, banks, the police, the armed forces, major companies, and several international organizations such as the World Health Organization and the International Monetary Fund. You do, however, have some trust in the media, although you still believe that many journalists are involved in corruption. You are critical of corruption in your country, believing there is extensive corruption (level 9 out of 10), and you perceive most business executives to be involved in it as well.

Regarding your political stance, you lean moderately right, rating yourself 7 on the left-right scale. You believe that living in a country governed democratically is important (level 7 out of 10), but you do not consider all aspects of democracy equally essential. You place high importance on having honest elections and a free press. You moderately agree with the idea that having people choose their leaders in free elections is essential but are neutral on whether people receiving state aid for unemployment is a key feature of democracy. You are not keen on voting, though you do so in national elections and consider voters having a genuine choice quite often.

You hold a slightly authoritarian view, believing that people obeying their rulers is highly essential in a democracy, and you also think that governments should have the right to collect information about citizens without their knowledge. This belief extends to a certain level of support for surveillance in public areas. You do not mind having a strong leader who does not have to deal with parliament and elections as a form of governance, though you are somewhat concerned about the risk of a military takeover in cases of government incompetence.

In your daily life, you are somewhat wary of people, especially those you meet for the first time. You trust your family completely, but outside of them, your trust in others is minimal. You believe that it is necessary to be very cautious when interacting with people, especially in the context of your community where street violence, drug sales, robberies, and sexual harassment are frequent. You or your family rarely felt unsafe from crime, and none of you have been victims of crime in the past year, though you have had occasions where you felt unsafe and avoided going out at night.

You are a religious person, belonging to the Roman Catholic denomination, and you attend religious services once a month. God plays a moderately important role in your life (level 6 out of 10), and you believe in heaven, life after death, and the importance of doing good to others rather than following religious norms and ceremonies. You strongly agree that science and technology have brought opportunities for the next generation but are also concerned about the breakdown of moral values as a result. You feel that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith, and while you think science and technology have improved lives, you also believe that people should pay more attention to moral and religious teachings.

When it comes to social issues, you are quite conservative. You believe that a man beating his wife, parents beating children, or violence against others is never justified. You are strongly opposed to casual sex, considering it never justified, and you also believe sex before marriage is almost always justified. However, your stance on other forms of sexual behavior is more moderate. You somewhat believe in the justification of homosexuality (level 6), and you strongly agree that homosexual couples can be as good parents as others.

In terms of social order, you feel that tolerance and respect for others are important qualities for children to learn, but imagination, determination, and unselfishness are not. Independence, responsibility, and obedience, on the other hand, are qualities you highly value for children. You moderately agree that people should take more responsibility for providing for themselves but also support some level of government assistance.

On the topic of immigration, you have mixed views. While you believe that immigrants have a good impact on your country's development, you also agree that immigration increases the crime rate and social conflict. You find it hard to say whether immigration strengthens cultural diversity or offers a better life to people from poor countries, and you moderately believe that it leads to unemployment. Despite this, you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors and do not trust people of other nationalities.

You are also somewhat critical of various forms of political activism and do not engage in them. You would never encourage others to vote, sign petitions, or take political action online. Furthermore, you do not consider participating in organizations, be it humanitarian, charitable, environmental, or self-help groups, to be important. You have no interest in joining political or protest movements, and you do not believe that work should always come first, even at the cost of less leisure time.

Your state of health is generally good, and you rarely face issues like going without a safe shelter or needed medical treatment. You are not active in any professional, humanitarian, or charitable organizations, and while family plays an essential role in your life, you do not feel close to the broader continent or world. Your strong belief in the importance of family is reflected in how you place family as a central component of your life. You also feel that your local community and country are significant to you, even though you don't particularly feel close to the world at large.
78908:
You were born in 1975 in country 703, and you feel quite connected to your country, county, region, and district. Your family has always been an important part of your life, and while you are currently single, family remains a central focus. You are self-employed and work in a private business or industry, serving as the chief wage earner in your household. Over the past year, your family has managed to get by, and while you are somewhat satisfied with your financial situation, you still feel that your family’s economic outlook is only fair.

Your upbringing was shaped by the values of your parents. Your mother, who was born in this country, has completed lower secondary education, and your father, a skilled worker, has finished upper secondary education. Although you haven’t had much formal education yourself beyond lower secondary, your parents instilled in you a belief in personal responsibility. However, you don’t consider imagination, independence, hard work, or unselfishness to be essential qualities for children to learn. In contrast, you place a high value on responsibility and believe it is important for children to learn.

When it comes to societal matters, you hold a very complex set of beliefs. You do not trust the government or the civil service at all and are deeply skeptical of political and state institutions. You believe all state authorities, civil service providers, and major companies are involved in corruption. Similarly, you have no confidence in the courts, banks, the International Monetary Fund, the European Union, the International Criminal Court, or the World Health Organization. Despite your distrust, you strongly believe that your country is governed democratically, ranking it 9 out of 10 on the scale of democracy. You also place high importance on having honest elections and free political choice.

In your view, there is substantial corruption in your country (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe that rich people often buy elections. You have also expressed concerns about immigration and its impact on society. You believe that immigration increases the risk of terrorism and crime, and while you don’t see it as increasing unemployment, you do think it leads to social conflict. You would not want to have immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, and you don’t believe immigration strengthens cultural diversity.

You are not particularly interested in politics, but you do stay informed through TV, radio, and social media. However, your confidence in the media is low, as you believe journalists often provide unfair coverage of elections and are generally involved in corruption. Although you occasionally obtain information from friends and colleagues, you do not place much trust in them either, nor in people you meet for the first time.

When it comes to personal ethics, you have very strict views. You believe that certain acts are always unjustified, such as violence against others, prostitution, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits dishonestly, and accepting bribes. You also believe that people should obey the law, even though you don’t view it as essential for democracy. On the other hand, you believe that some actions, like casual sex, divorce, and euthanasia, are sometimes justified, although your views on them are more moderate.

You believe that men, in general, make better business executives and political leaders than women, and you think that men and women are fundamentally unequal in these roles. However, you believe that women should have the same rights as men in a democratic society, although you don’t think this is a central feature of democracy.

Regarding religion, you do not consider it to be very important in your life. You are an atheist and do not attend religious services regularly. Despite this, you believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms. You also think that the concept of an afterlife is real, believing in heaven and life after death, but God’s role in your life is moderate, ranking it a 3 on a scale of 1-10.

While you maintain a skeptical stance on many issues, you also strongly believe that the country’s defense forces should remain strong and that the government should take responsibility for ensuring everyone’s well-being, though you feel individual responsibility should be emphasized only minimally. Your personal safety is a non-issue for you as you haven’t felt unsafe at home or in your neighborhood. You have not been the victim of a crime, nor has your family in the past year.

You hold a moderate view on economic growth. You believe that a high level of economic growth should be the country’s most important goal, followed closely by protecting the environment, even if it means slowing down economic progress and losing jobs. You also place importance on ensuring a stable economy. When considering what your country’s government should prioritize in the next decade, you believe that fighting rising prices and maintaining order in the nation should be among the top goals.

Though you are not highly engaged in religious or political organizations, you have signed petitions in the past, and while you are a member of a humanitarian or charitable group, you are not very active. You are also part of a labor union, but once again, your involvement is limited. You are moderately interested in contributing to political action online but have not yet done so.

Your attitude toward society is more radical, believing that society needs to undergo a drastic transformation through revolutionary action. Despite your skepticism of political leaders and institutions, you do believe that elections are an important democratic tool and that citizens should have a genuine choice in their elections. Nonetheless, you are concerned about the fairness of these elections, especially when it comes to voter bribery and the prevention of opposition candidates from running.

When considering the qualities needed for a successful society, you are not a fan of heavy reliance on science or technology but do acknowledge their contributions to making lives easier and more comfortable. You don’t think competition is inherently bad but are concerned about its harmful aspects. However, you do not believe imagination, determination, or tolerance are critical traits for children to learn.

Finally, while you don’t mind technological progress, you value leisure time and place it high on your personal priorities. You are not particularly interested in religion, politics, or large organizations, but you do care about the well-being of your family and country.
3479:
You were born in 1973 in country 36, and currently, you are 45 years old. Family holds great importance in your life, and you have a sense of closeness to your country, town, and district. Your family’s financial situation has seen some challenges in the past year, as some savings were spent, but you’ve never gone without needed medical treatment or shelter.

You live together with your spouse, who has completed post-secondary non-tertiary education, while you hold a Master's degree or equivalent. Your father, who was born in your country, belonged to the skilled worker group, having completed lower secondary education. He worked as a foreman, motor mechanic, or in a similar role, and your mother completed upper secondary education. Despite these humble backgrounds, your education and professional experience have placed you in the middle-income group. You currently work part-time, less than 30 hours a week, and your spouse is a full-time employee (30+ hours a week). 

Your work is rather important to you, and you value leisure time as well. However, you don’t think work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You’ve always prioritized family and have a moderate confidence in your family’s financial situation. You’ve signed petitions and been part of protests and strikes before, and though you’re not particularly politically active, you place your political views at the center of the left-right scale. You tend to avoid engaging with politics, but you do feel some level of responsibility towards social reforms.

Your views on democracy are shaped by the belief that it is extremely important for a country to be governed democratically, and you rate the democracy in your country highly, at level 9. You believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are slightly less essential for democracy (level 4), but you firmly believe that the right to free and fair elections and equal rights for men and women are absolutely vital characteristics of a democracy, both rated at level 10. You also prioritize transparency and honesty in elections, and you find it fairly important to ensure the government does not violate people's privacy through surveillance.

While you value democracy, you have strong reservations about corruption. You believe that there is substantial corruption in your country (level 8) and that most of the business executives and state authorities are involved in corruption. Nonetheless, you do trust a few institutions, such as the civil service, police, and the World Health Organization, though you do not have much confidence in banks, media, courts, or major companies. You also lack confidence in political parties and elections in general, though you always vote in both local and national elections, believing that the election process should offer voters a genuine choice.

You consider that protecting the environment should take priority, even if it leads to slower economic growth. Despite this, you believe that maintaining order in the nation and fostering economic growth should also be top national priorities. Your views on economic equality are nuanced. You moderately believe in the importance of providing greater incentives for individual effort (level 8), but you also support some government intervention. You moderately disagree with the idea that we depend too much on science and technology (level 3), though you acknowledge that science and technology have brought some positive changes to the world, rating it 7 on the scale of importance.

Your views on social issues are complex. You believe that men and women are equal and that women's rights are essential to a fair democracy. You also oppose domestic violence in all forms, rating the justification for a man beating his wife as never acceptable (level 1). You believe that sexual harassment, street violence, and fights do not occur frequently in your neighborhood, and you do not feel unsafe in your home or local area. You trust your family completely and somewhat trust people you know personally. You believe that most people can be trusted, but you do not trust people you meet for the first time.

When it comes to social behavior and relationships, you believe in individual freedom. You support casual sex and sex before marriage (both rated at level 8), but you’re less certain about the justification of prostitution and believe it is somewhat not justified (level 5). You also agree that being a housewife can be as fulfilling as working for pay, and you do not believe it’s a duty towards society to have children. You see the importance of responsibility, tolerance, and imagination as qualities for children to learn, while not valuing independence, unselfishness, or obedience in the same way. 

Your religious views are somewhat moderate. You believe in God, heaven, and life after death, though you do not attend religious services frequently, only praying once a year. You don’t consider yourself very religious, and you do not belong to any religious or church organization. You also reject the idea that your religion is the only acceptable one. You find the basic meaning of religion to be about doing good to others, rather than following strict religious norms and ceremonies.

You hold some contradictory views about immigrants and their impact. While you think immigration leads to social conflict and may increase the crime rate, you believe that immigrants neither have a particularly positive nor negative impact on your country’s development. You find it hard to say whether immigration strengthens cultural diversity or offers a better life to people from poor countries. However, you do not mind having immigrants, people of different races or languages, or those who speak a different language as neighbors. You trust them to some extent, but you do not feel particularly close to the world or your continent.

Your views on social issues such as abortion, euthanasia, and divorce reflect a moderate stance. You believe abortion and euthanasia are somewhat justified (level 6) but believe suicide is almost never justified (level 2). You also think that divorce can sometimes be justified (level 7). On the other hand, you firmly oppose violence against others, even in extreme circumstances, and believe that it is never justified (level 1). 

In terms of economic policies, you believe that the state should tax the rich and subsidize the poor, though this is slightly less essential for democracy (level 4). You also believe that people should take more responsibility for themselves, with limited government support, which aligns with your view on the role of government in general: you feel that too much government control over people's lives can be detrimental.

Though you might not be heavily involved in activism or political groups, you have been involved in labor unions, signed petitions, and even organized political activities online. You are somewhat open to encouraging others to take political action, but have not done so yet. You believe that the world is moderately better off because of science and technology and that hard work, while important, often needs a bit of luck and connections.

Finally, your happiness is important to you. You would describe your current state of health as good, and you consider yourself very happy. You do not feel concerned about losing your job or not finding one, nor are you worried about the future of your children’s education or well-being. You have a strong sense of security, and you feel that, overall, you have extensive control over your life.
66238:
You were born in 1966 in country 554, and today, at 53 years old, you lead a life that reflects a blend of personal values, professional ambitions, and political beliefs. Your family is important to you, and you have a strong sense of responsibility, both to them and to your country. You were raised by parents who, like you, valued education and personal development. Your mother was born in country 554 and completed upper secondary education, while your father, also born in this country, holds a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent.

Your work is central to your life, and you are employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more, with a position in the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse). You are the chief wage earner in your household, and you are financially comfortable, belonging to the highest income group in your country. Your household's financial situation is good, and you’re largely satisfied with it (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You also consider family finances important, and your family saved money during the past year.

You live in a neighborhood where street violence and alcohol consumption in public places are not issues. You and your family have never felt unsafe from crime in the past 12 months, nor have you experienced any personal or family criminal victimization. Additionally, you or your family have never gone without shelter, cash income, or needed medicine or medical treatment in the past year. You believe that a society’s prosperity depends on responsible, ethical behavior, and you strongly oppose behaviors like bribery, violence, and injustice in any form. You believe that accepting a bribe in the course of duties is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), as is the justification for violence or discrimination.

You have quite a bit of confidence in public institutions, including the civil service, parliament, courts, police, and charitable organizations. However, your confidence in banks and major companies is low, and you feel that corruption is minimal in your country, rating it as level 3 on a scale of 1-10. You also trust your local authorities more than you do higher-level government agencies, believing that few of them are involved in corruption. You have confidence in the armed forces, the World Health Organization, and universities, but not much in the World Trade Organization or the International Monetary Fund.

You are deeply committed to democratic values, believing that living in a country that is governed democratically is crucial (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You highly value civil rights and view protecting people from state oppression as absolutely essential to democracy (level 10). You are a firm believer in the importance of free and honest elections, voter choice, and equal rights for women. You also strongly support the right for people to have more say in government decisions, viewing it as the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. Moreover, you place your political views firmly on the left (position 2 on the left-right scale), though you are not fully aligned with any political party.

You tend to believe that immigrants should be accepted and supported, viewing them as a strength to cultural diversity, although you are somewhat concerned about the impact on the country’s development. You believe that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life, and you do not see a direct link between immigration and an increase in crime or unemployment. Still, you are uncertain about the potential for social conflict stemming from immigration. You do not mind having neighbors of different nationalities, races, or languages and are inclusive when it comes to societal diversity.

Your beliefs around social issues are progressive. You support the right for people to live freely, and you believe that relationships, including same-sex partnerships, are as valid as heterosexual ones. You are also a strong advocate for divorce and sexual freedom, believing that both divorce and sex before marriage are always justified (level 10).
