You do not believe in hell, heaven, or life after death, aligning yourself with atheism. You do not attend religious services, and you do not belong to any religious denomination or organization. Instead, you see the basic meaning of religion as a way to do good to others rather than to follow strict religious norms.

In terms of societal progress, you value progress toward a more humane and less impersonal society, and you believe in the importance of ensuring that ideas count more than money. You view responsibility as a key quality for children to learn, but you do not consider imagination, independence, or religious faith to be essential qualities. You also place importance on the idea of unselfishness in children. You think that a feeling of responsibility for others and a tolerance for diversity are vital lessons for future generations.

You are moderately interested in politics, but not so much that it occupies all of your time. You obtain most of your political information online daily, but you also keep up with the news through radio and social media. You occasionally talk to friends or colleagues about current events, but you are not deeply involved in any political activities. While you would not mind organizing political events or protests online, you have not yet done so. You believe that journalists do not always provide fair coverage of elections, and you are concerned about the influence of money in politics, though you do not think it’s a widespread problem in your country. You are a regular voter, always participating in national and local elections, and you encourage others to vote as well.

While you support a government role in ensuring everyone is provided for, you believe there should be a balance between government responsibility and individual responsibility, with a slight preference for the latter. However, you do not believe that the state should force income equality. You moderately believe that hard work leads to a better life but recognize that luck and connections can play a role. You do not think competition should be overly emphasized, but you do believe it has benefits.

You are a member of a labor union, though not actively involved, and you’ve signed petitions in the past. Despite this, you have not taken a strong stance on social movements or humanitarian causes, nor do you belong to any charitable or humanitarian organizations. However, you believe the government should take more responsibility for providing for its citizens and that ensuring fairness in elections and democracy is key.

While you prioritize work, you believe leisure time is also important, and you disagree with the notion that work should always come first, even at the expense of spare time. You also value having a strong connection with your community, your city, and your continent, although you do not feel very close to the world at large. Your worldview is deeply rooted in democratic ideals and a belief in individual freedoms and rights, with a strong commitment to the notion that social reforms will gradually improve society.

You are married to someone who holds a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent, and both of you are full-time employees. You believe in gender equality, rejecting the notion that men make better leaders or business executives than women. Your spouse shares your values and intellectual background, and together, you live a comfortable and secure life, with a sense of responsibility toward both your immediate family and your broader society.
93851:
You were born in 1994 in country 862, and you currently live in this country with your spouse, who is or was self-employed. You are 27 years old and have a fair state of health. You are a housewife, not otherwise employed, and you feel that family is very important in your life. You were raised with a strong belief in God, which remains central to your life today, and you attend religious services once a week. You consider yourself a religious person and believe that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life in this world rather than after death.

Your mother, who was born in your country, completed primary education, as did your father, who belongs to the unskilled worker group. Your father has completed upper secondary education. Your family has had its share of financial challenges, with your household occasionally going without a cash income and sometimes going without needed medicine or medical treatment in the past year. You consider yourself to be part of the middle-income group in your country, but you are very dissatisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). Over the past year, your family has just gotten by, and you feel worried about not being able to provide your children with a good education in the future.

In terms of political beliefs, you place your views strongly on the right (position 9 on the left-right scale). You are not very interested in politics, and you do not belong to any political or other types of organizations. You would never sign a petition, never organize political activities online, and never encourage others to take political action. You do not trust the government, and you have little confidence in various institutions, including the civil service, the courts, banks, the police, political parties, and most of the media, which you believe is largely corrupt. You do not have confidence in the European Union, international organizations, or the World Trade Organization, and you feel worried about the risk of a civil war or a war involving your country.

You value the importance of a democratic society but have some mixed views on the essentials of democracy. You believe your country is extremely democratic (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), but you also think that international organizations should prioritize effectiveness over being democratic (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You place a high value on having honest elections and believe that ensuring strong defense forces should be the second most important goal for your country over the next decade. However, you also believe that corruption is widespread within your country’s political system, including among civil service providers, business executives, and local authorities. You do not trust election officials or journalists to provide fair coverage of elections, and you think that elections are often influenced by bribery.

You also hold strong views on various social issues. You believe that violence against others, including domestic violence, is never justified. You feel that a man beating his wife or parents beating children is never acceptable (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also reject the idea of abortion, euthanasia, prostitution, and terrorism as political or ideological means, all of which you believe are never justified. Similarly, you hold the belief that cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and engaging in fare evasion are never justified.

When it comes to family values and child-rearing, you hold certain qualities in high regard. You believe that children should learn the importance of independence, responsibility, and obedience. You do not consider imagination, religious faith, or determination as particularly important qualities for children to learn, but you place a high value on respect for others and tolerance. You also think it’s essential that children learn about the importance of hard work, though you do not believe it is the most important quality. Additionally, you think it’s crucial for children to understand that work should come first, even if it means sacrificing leisure time.

Your views on society and progress are more nuanced. You believe that economic growth and job creation should be a top priority, even if it comes at the expense of the environment. You also think it’s important to ensure that people take more responsibility for their own well-being, though you support some degree of government involvement. You believe that competition can be harmful, but you also appreciate its benefits. You think that technology development should be emphasized and that a society that values ideas over money would be ideal.

Despite your strong religious faith, you are not affiliated with any religious denomination or group, nor do you belong to any professional, humanitarian, or charitable organization. You do not trust people you meet for the first time very much and believe that ordinary people like yourself rarely have to deal with bribery to obtain services. You also feel that work is extremely important in your life, but it should never overshadow family or leisure time.

In your personal life, you believe that personal freedom is more important than security, though you are worried about the risk of losing your job or not finding one. You are neutral about whether immigration strengthens cultural diversity, increases the crime rate, or leads to social conflict, but you believe that immigrants have neither a good nor bad impact on the development of your country. You do not mind having people of different races, languages, or nationalities as neighbors, although you would not want to have drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS living next door.

You do not trust your neighborhood very much and have avoided going out at night for security reasons. However, you have never been the victim of a crime in the past year, and neither has your family. You believe that street violence, robberies, and drug sales do not occur frequently in your neighborhood. You also feel that your neighborhood is relatively safe in comparison to other areas.

Although you believe that society must gradually improve through reforms, you are very dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country. You do not trust most institutions or people involved in the government and believe that corruption is a major problem. Despite all these concerns, you are quite happy with your life overall and feel very close to your village, town, or city, as well as to your continent and the world.
73564:
You were born in a country with a rich history and deep cultural roots, in the year -2, making you part of a family with a strong sense of place. Your mother was born in the same country, and your father hails from the same place as well. Family holds a central place in your life, and you have always felt deeply connected to both your immediate and extended family. You are married, and together with your spouse, you have created a life that reflects your values and beliefs.

Currently, you are a housewife, not otherwise employed, a role that you view as fulfilling and important. While you have some interest in working, you believe strongly that your role as a homemaker is integral to your family's well-being and happiness. You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society, but you also believe that leisure time is important in your life. You hold a belief that work should come first, even if it means less spare time, but at the same time, you do value balance.

Your family’s financial situation is stable and secure, as evidenced by the fact that you have never gone without a safe shelter or cash income in the last year. You are also very satisfied with your household's financial situation (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). Your family saved money during the past year, a reflection of your strong belief in thrift, saving, and financial security. You belong to the seventh highest income group in your country, which places you in a relatively comfortable economic position.

Your confidence in various societal institutions is notable. You have a great deal of confidence in the civil service, in banks, and in charitable or humanitarian organizations. You trust your family completely, and you also place a high degree of trust in political parties, parliament, and the courts. You feel secure in your neighborhood, and crime has not been a concern for you in the past year. You have a strong belief that people obeying their rulers is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and that the country is currently governed democratically (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Despite these positive views, you believe there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), but you feel that most local authorities and civil service providers are not involved in corruption.

You are deeply interested in politics and consider it quite important in your life. You actively seek out information through various media, including TV news, radio, social media, and discussions with friends or colleagues. You believe the country’s elections are largely fair and that voters are generally offered a genuine choice, although you are not without concerns, as you believe opposition candidates are often prevented from running fairly. You have even organized political activities and protests online, demonstrating your active participation in political affairs. You strongly believe that having honest elections is very important, and that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).

You have strong views about the role of government in society. You believe the government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) but also think that the state should not have the right to collect information about anyone living in the country without their knowledge. You believe in the importance of a stable economy and economic growth (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), as well as job creation. You think that government ownership of business and industry should be increased somewhat, with support for private ownership (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). In your view, the state should also tax the rich and subsidize the poor (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).

Your beliefs regarding social issues are shaped by a deep sense of moral responsibility. You strongly believe that people should respect the law and that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than to follow religious norms. While you are a member of the Orthodox faith, your views on religion are not rigid; you attend religious services only on special holy days and consider God moderately important in your life (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe in heaven and hell, and you place some importance on hard work and unselfishness as qualities for children to learn. You place less emphasis on imagination or obedience, considering them less essential qualities for children. 

You believe in the importance of personal responsibility and family values. You consider hard work, thrift, saving money, determination, perseverance, and unselfishness as key qualities for children to learn. You also believe that raising children in an environment that prioritizes values like independence and responsibility is crucial, and you feel strongly that work is a duty towards society. You have a slight preference for the idea that government should support individual efforts with limited incentives for income equality (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).

In terms of your views on social issues, you are somewhat moderate. You do not believe that casual sex is justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10) and think that sex before marriage is often justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You also slightly agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). Your opinion about society is that it should be changed by revolutionary action, although you do not feel very close to the world or the larger global community. You do not mind having neighbors of different races or speaking different languages, and you consider it fairly good to have a diverse range of people in your community.

Your views on immigration are somewhat neutral. You believe immigrants do not have a good or bad impact on your country’s development, though you agree that immigration increases the crime rate. You also think that immigration might lead to social conflict but find it hard to say definitively. You do not believe that immigration offers a better life to people from poor countries, and you feel that immigration might increase unemployment. At the same time, you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.

Despite these opinions on society and culture, you strongly believe in the importance of protecting civil rights and freedoms. You are particularly passionate about ensuring freedom of speech, and you believe that women having the same rights as men is an essential characteristic of democracy. You believe in a government that maintains civil liberties while also ensuring that the country is secure, with strong defense forces. You are also convinced that scientific advancements are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable, though you are aware that they sometimes challenge traditional views of right and wrong.
85182:
You were born in 1971 in country 792, and you are 47 years old. You are currently married, and your spouse works part-time, less than 30 hours a week. You are the chief wage earner in your household, which places you within the middle income group of your country. You would describe your state of health these days as good, and your family rarely went without a safe shelter or medical treatment in the last 12 months. Your financial situation is moderately satisfactory, rated at 7 on a scale of 1-10.

Work holds significant importance in your life, and you consider it a duty towards society. Although you don't always prioritize work over leisure, you agree that work is an important societal responsibility. Leisure time is also very important to you, and you believe that your children should learn qualities like determination and perseverance, but not imagination or unselfishness. In fact, you don't consider imagination, independence, or tolerance for others to be essential qualities for children to learn.

You are employed part-time and work in the private business or industry sector. You trust your family somewhat and consider hard work an important quality for your children to learn. You belong to the higher administrative group, such as a banker, executive in a large business, or high government official. You have quite a lot of confidence in the civil service, government, parliament, and various organizations like the World Health Organization and the European Union. Despite your trust in many institutions, you have low confidence in the police, courts, and banks.

You are a citizen of this country and hold moderately conservative political views, positioning yourself as strongly right-leaning. You are somewhat interested in politics, and though you are not a member of any political party, you might encourage others to vote or take political action online. You consider the development of technology and ensuring a strong defense as important goals for the country over the next decade. However, you are also concerned about the social and economic stability, believing that addressing rising prices should be a top priority.

Regarding the political system, you feel it would be a good thing to have experts, not the government, make decisions for the country. You somewhat believe that people should take more responsibility for their own lives, though you still see a role for the government in assisting people. You believe in the importance of economic growth and job creation, even if it comes at the expense of the environment. You believe that the country’s elections are somewhat fair, though you feel that opposition candidates are often unfairly prevented from running. You also believe that voters are bribed fairly often during elections.

In terms of your beliefs, you are a religious person, and your faith is somewhat important in your life, rated at 6 on a scale of 1-10. You attend religious services more than once a week and believe that the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death. You do not belong to any religious organization but consider yourself a member of the Muslim denomination. You believe in heaven and hell, and you feel that religious authorities should not have the ultimate authority over interpreting laws. Your mother was born in your country, and your father worked in a farming-related industry as a farm proprietor or manager. Your family spent some savings during the past year, but you rarely went without cash income.

When it comes to societal issues, you are moderately concerned about the state of democracy in your country. You believe that the country is moderately democratic (5 out of 10), and you slightly prioritize democracy over efficiency when it comes to international organizations. You value civil rights and believe that protecting people from state oppression is essential, although not crucial. However, you are neutral about the importance of free elections and the right to choose leaders. You also slightly disagree that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, though you believe that immigrants have a positive impact on the development of your country. Despite this, you worry about issues like unemployment and feel that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize citizens over immigrants. You do not consider immigration as providing a better life for people from poor countries.

On social issues, you hold a variety of opinions. You do not justify casual sex, prostitution, or divorce, though you are neutral about some aspects like sexual harassment and whether parents beating children is ever justified. You believe that violence against others is rarely justified and that corruption is noticeable in your country, but you trust that civil servants are not involved in corruption. You believe the government should not have the right to surveil citizens without their knowledge and that it is essential for the state to make people's incomes more equal. You feel somewhat secure these days and trust that ordinary people do not often have to bribe public officials.

You are moderately satisfied with the political system in your country, rating it at a 6 out of 10, though you feel that journalists do not provide fair coverage of elections. You have no strong opinions on whether science and technology make life healthier, easier, or more comfortable, but you believe that they make the world slightly better off. You hold some reservations about the overreliance on science, feeling that we depend too much on it rather than faith. Despite this, you value economic growth and the development of technology for future generations, even though you feel that science sometimes breaks down people’s moral understanding.

You place a moderate importance on civil rights, feeling that people should have a say in government decisions, but you do not prioritize having honest elections or ensuring that women and men have equal rights. You feel that some government benefits and the right to avoid paying for public transport should not be justified, and you somewhat disagree with the notion of providing equal rights for women.

On family matters, you hold your family in high regard, but you don't prioritize the role of women in childrearing or supporting the household financially. You disagree with the idea that mothers working for pay negatively impacts children, but you still believe that children should learn qualities like thrift and perseverance, rather than imagination or tolerance. Despite your strong work ethic and involvement in political issues, you maintain a balanced view of society and trust that gradual reforms will improve the nation.
91925:
You were born in 1974 in your country and currently live in a stable environment. Your family plays a significant role in your life, and you hold strong values regarding responsibility, hard work, and family unity. You are married and your spouse holds a Doctoral degree or equivalent. You both share a reasonably comfortable life, and you belong to the highest income group in your country. You would describe your financial situation as quite satisfactory (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you consider yourself relatively better off compared to your parents when they were your age. Your family has saved money over the past year, and neither you nor your family have gone without a cash income or needed medical treatment in the last 12 months.

Although you are currently unemployed, you feel substantial freedom of choice and control over the direction of your life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Your educational background is notable, as you hold a Doctoral degree or equivalent, and you have worked in the private business or industry sector. Your spouse has a similar level of education, having also attained a Doctoral degree or equivalent.

You hold certain views about democracy, governance, and the role of government in society. You believe that your country is very democratic in how it is governed today (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you see strong defense forces as the second most important goal for the country over the next decade. You believe that democracy is characterized by having free elections, ensuring gender equality, and providing civil rights. You place a high priority on the freedom of speech and the protection of civil rights, even though you feel that the characteristic of governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is somewhat not essential for democracy (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly believe that women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you reject the idea that men make better business executives or political leaders than women. You also believe that having honest elections is of great importance to you, and that voters should have a genuine choice very often in the elections. Additionally, you are not concerned about a potential civil war or war involving your country.

While you place great importance on democracy, you also express some concerns about corruption in your country. You believe there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), and you think there is a considerable risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor in return for public services (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). Despite this, you have confidence in various institutions, including the civil service, charitable organizations, the armed forces, the courts, and the police. You feel relatively secure and are not particularly worried about crime or losing your job. Your neighborhood is generally free of crime, with incidents of street violence, robberies, and drug sales being rare.

You are moderately interested in politics and follow the news daily, whether through TV, radio, or the Internet. You actively engage in discussions with friends or colleagues and sometimes seek information about politics and political events online. You support certain political activities, such as signing petitions and potentially organizing or encouraging political action online. While you feel somewhat dissatisfied with the political system in your country (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), you believe the country’s electoral system is fair and that journalists provide fair coverage of elections. You trust the people around you somewhat, but not as much as those you know personally, and generally, you believe that most people can be trusted. You place your political views on the moderately right side of the spectrum (level 7 on the left-right scale).

Your views on social issues are shaped by your personal values. You believe that having a sense of responsibility, determination, and perseverance is important for children to learn. You also emphasize the importance of imagination and hard work as essential qualities for children. You consider family to be an important aspect of your life, and you place a high value on education, though you do not feel it is an essential characteristic for children to learn independence or obedience. You are not particularly close to your continent, region, or district but do feel connected to your country, despite being somewhat distant from the world as a whole. You consider yourself a religious person, and while you believe in God, you do not hold religion as the ultimate guiding principle in your life. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and you attend religious services only on special holy days.

Regarding your views on marriage, you are somewhat against divorce (level 5 on a scale of 1-10) and believe that sex before marriage and casual sex are somewhat not justified (both level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You also consider prostitution and euthanasia rarely justified (level 3 and level 4 on a scale of 1-10, respectively). You strongly disagree with violence in any form, and you believe that terrorism, the beating of wives, and cheating on taxes are never justified (all rated level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that people should not accept bribes or engage in corruption, viewing such actions as completely unjustifiable.

In terms of global issues, you have a rather negative view of immigration, believing it can have a bad impact on the development of your country, lead to social conflict, and increase the risks of terrorism. You do not feel very close to your village, town, or city, and you think immigration might also be associated with an increase in unemployment, although you find it hard to say whether immigration increases crime rates. Despite these concerns, you do agree that immigration offers people from poorer countries a better life and strengthens cultural diversity. 

Your approach to life is one of practical realism, and you believe that people should take more responsibility for providing for themselves, with limited emphasis on government intervention (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately support the idea that individual effort should be incentivized, but with some support for income equality (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that competition is generally beneficial (level 2 on a scale of 1-10), but you consider the development of technology to be an important area for future emphasis, even if it comes at the cost of slower economic growth or job losses.

Your political and social views reflect a commitment to personal freedom, individual responsibility, and democratic values, even as you wrestle with some of the complexities and challenges these issues present. You value work and the role it plays in society, and while you believe work is important, you also see leisure time as important. You might participate in political action or encourage others to vote or take part in some form of online political activities, but for now, you are primarily an observer. Your vision for the future includes protecting civil liberties and promoting a robust economy, but you are also cautious about potential social and political issues, such as corruption and the impact of immigration.
71427:
You were born in 1947 in country 608, a place you feel somewhat connected to, but your sense of belonging is much stronger with your village, town, or city. Your family has always been central to your life, and while your family just got by during the past year, you've experienced a much higher standard of living compared to your parents when they were about your age. This gives you a sense of progress, though financial stability has been somewhat limited, as you belong to the second-lowest income group in your country.

At 72 years old, you are actively employed full-time, working 30 hours or more a week, and you place a high importance on work in your life. You believe that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time, and you view it as a duty towards society. Despite this, you also believe that leisure time isn’t very important to you, and you don’t particularly mind if there’s a greater emphasis on the development of technology, although you find it somewhat concerning if technology overshadows the essence of human life. Your role as the chief wage earner in your household shows your strong commitment to maintaining financial stability, and you are very satisfied with your household's financial situation (level 9 out of 10). However, it is also true that you or your family have sometimes gone without needed medical treatment or medicine in the last year.

In your perspective, your country is somewhat democratic, rating it a 6 out of 10, and you moderately believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased, with a stronger inclination towards public rather than private ownership (level 8 out of 10). You also believe that having honest elections is rather important and that the state should be involved in making people's incomes equal, though you don't view it as a central element of democracy. You strongly agree that the world is slightly better off due to the advances in science and technology (level 6 out of 10), and you place a very high value on living in a country that is governed democratically (level 9 out of 10). 

Though you maintain quite a lot of confidence in key institutions such as the police, courts, and the government, you view corruption as a significant issue, especially within your country's local and state authorities. You believe there is considerable corruption overall (level 7 out of 10), yet you trust civil service providers, banks, the armed forces, and the World Health Organization to an extent. You find the idea of being governed by a strong leader without the bother of parliament and elections somewhat appealing, reflecting your preference for more decisive leadership in times of crisis. 

Politically, you place yourself at the center of the left-right spectrum, though your views on various issues are quite nuanced. You are neutral about some democratic characteristics, such as whether civil rights protecting people from state oppression or voters having a genuine choice in elections are essential. You find that the government should sometimes have the right to collect personal information about its citizens, yet you also believe in the importance of voters having a free and fair election. However, you are also somewhat concerned about the increasing risk of terrorism related to immigration and the possible rise in social conflict due to immigration. Despite these concerns, you acknowledge the positive aspects of cultural diversity brought about by immigration. 

In terms of social and moral views, you are deeply religious, belonging to the Roman Catholic denomination, and believe that God is extremely important in your life (level 9 out of 10). You attend religious services more than once a week and pray several times a day. You hold that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and you do not view religious faith as an important quality for children to learn, preferring that they learn obedience, hard work, and respect for others. You also believe that religious authorities should have a role in interpreting the laws. While you strongly disagree with the idea that women are less corrupt than men, you do not agree with the idea that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, nor would you like to have homosexuals, people with AIDS, or immigrants as neighbors. 

Your family background plays a significant role in shaping your values. Your mother, who had no formal education or only early childhood education, was born in your home country, while your father, also lacking formal education, came from a background in farm ownership. Both of your parents’ lack of formal education might have impacted your views on education and work, as you consider hard work a key quality for children to learn, but you do not prioritize independence or imagination. You also do not consider thrift or unselfishness as important qualities for children, reflecting your broader worldview where practicality and responsibility take precedence.

Though you don’t belong to any labor unions, professional organizations, or environmental groups, you are actively involved in a church or religious organization and are somewhat interested in politics. You believe that people should have more say in how things are done at their jobs and in their communities, ranking this as the most important goal for your country in the next decade. You also somewhat believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with some emphasis on government responsibility.

You do not have very much confidence in international organizations such as the World Trade Organization or the International Monetary Fund, but you do have faith in the European Union and other regional organizations. You are very skeptical of corruption in the media, journalists, and big corporations, yet you trust banks, charitable organizations, and humanitarian groups. In terms of personal responsibility, you believe claiming government benefits without entitlement is almost never justified, and you view violence as sometimes justified when necessary (level 7 out of 10). 

As someone who believes in both heaven and hell, your worldview is heavily influenced by your faith and your deep commitment to traditional values, including the idea that men make better business executives than women and the importance of preserving order in the nation. You also strongly believe in the sanctity of life, ranking euthanasia as almost never justified and abortion as rarely justified. However, your views on some issues are more flexible—such as the necessity of sexual equality, where you believe that women should have the same rights as men, but that women having more access to education might not be as crucial for them as it is for boys. 

While you are relatively happy with your life, the future still brings concerns, such as the potential for increased unemployment, the possibility of not providing a good education for your children, and the threat of crime and terrorism. You might even sign a petition or encourage others to vote, believing that participation in political matters is important. At the same time, you also think that people should be very careful when dealing with others and that your strong views on both democracy and the importance of family continue to guide you in how you live your life.

Despite the complexities in your beliefs, one constant remains: your trust in the people and institutions closest to you, whether that’s your family, your neighborhood, or your church. You do not feel very close to your continent or the world, but you are secure within your local surroundings.
26063:
You were born in 1978 in Country 231, and you have a deep sense of connection to both your country and the place where you live, feeling quite close to your village, town, or city. Your mother was born in the same country, but she had only early childhood education, as did your father. Despite their limited formal schooling, they worked hard to provide for the family. Your father belonged to the farm worker group, and your mother was the primary caretaker. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and your spouse, who has also received only early childhood education, is or was unemployed.

Your family’s financial situation over the past year has been less than ideal, with the household occasionally going without a cash income, though no one went without needed medicine or medical treatment. You would describe your financial situation as largely unsatisfactory (level 3 out of 10). This has shaped your views on work and personal responsibility. You strongly believe that work is a duty toward society and that it should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You hold a high regard for the importance of hard work, although you don’t think it’s an important quality for children to learn. 

You are self-employed, and work is extremely important to you. You hold a great deal of confidence in businesses, including major companies and banks, and believe in the power of economic growth, which you consider to be the second most important goal for the country over the next ten years. At the same time, you believe the standard of living today is better than what your parents had when they were your age. 

Your life revolves heavily around your religious beliefs. God is central to your existence, and you attend religious services more than once a week. You pray several times a day, and you believe that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, rather than to help others. You consider yourself a deeply religious person, and you strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. This belief extends to your view on religious education, as you consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn.

You are married, and your family life is significant to you, though you also believe that having children is a duty toward society. You strongly agree that having children is vital for the future. Despite your strong religious views, you hold somewhat more progressive views regarding gender roles, particularly when it comes to women’s rights. You believe that women should have the same rights as men, though you are still somewhat traditional in your approach to other aspects of gender roles, including the belief that men generally make better political leaders and business executives than women. 

When it comes to governance, you are somewhat dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 3 out of 10), and you do not trust the political process, especially regarding the fairness of elections and the honesty of election officials. You believe that voters are often bribed, and the elections in your country do not offer a genuine choice. However, you do consider it important that elections remain honest and that people are allowed to choose their leaders in free elections, even if you’re neutral about whether governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is essential to democracy. You hold a moderately positive view of democracy but do not think it’s being practiced as well as it could be, rating the democratic quality of your country at a 5 out of 10. 

Despite your dissatisfaction with your country’s politics, you do not engage in political activities. You are not a member of any political party or social movement and would never encourage others to take political action, either online or offline. You don’t obtain information about politics from the Internet or social media, and you prefer traditional sources of information, such as TV and radio news, which you follow weekly and daily, respectively. You are also not a member of any charitable, professional, or environmental organization, nor any sport or recreational group.

While you have confidence in certain institutions, such as the civil service, the armed forces, and the courts, you are highly critical of corruption within your country. You believe corruption is widespread, with most civil service providers and local authorities involved, though you do not believe that business executives are involved in corruption. You are concerned about the level of corruption but trust major international organizations such as the International Criminal Court, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, and the International Monetary Fund.

On social issues, you are quite conservative. You strongly believe that abortion, suicide, divorce, prostitution, casual sex, and sex before marriage are never justified, each rated 1 out of 10 in terms of justification. You also think that violence against other people is never justified and hold a strict view on personal responsibility and moral conduct. You believe that people should never accept bribes, cheat on taxes, or avoid fares on public transport. In terms of your personal life, you are deeply opposed to any form of sexual immorality and believe that homosexuality, in all forms, is never justified.

You believe that family is extremely important and that you should protect your family and neighborhood from the risks of crime. However, despite living in a generally safe environment, you are cautious about your personal security and have sometimes avoided going out at night for safety reasons. You also consider security to be more important than freedom when it comes to personal priorities. 

Regarding your broader views on society, you are not particularly concerned about the global community and don’t feel close to the world at large. You have a neutral stance toward the development of other cultures, and you believe that immigration generally harms your country’s development. You are not a supporter of immigration for economic, social, or cultural reasons and believe immigrants negatively impact the country's growth. You also do not think that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, and you are concerned about the effects of immigrants on the job market and crime rates. You are concerned about the potential risks of immigration, and you would prioritize native citizens over immigrants in a scarce job market.

Despite your concerns about immigration and the political landscape, you remain optimistic about your personal and family life. You strongly agree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl, and you feel it is essential for your children to have a good education. You are worried, however, about not being able to provide that for them. You also believe that having a high level of economic growth should be a top priority for your country. 

You have a relatively stable view of your personal life, as you rarely feel unsafe from crime, and you have never experienced a break-in or robbery in your neighborhood. Your neighborhood is quiet, with no incidents of street violence, sexual harassment, or drug sales. You also believe that alcohol consumption in public is not a frequent occurrence in your neighborhood.

Overall, you have a strong sense of personal responsibility, a deep commitment to religion, and an unwavering belief in the importance of work and family. You trust a select group of institutions, but your confidence in the political system and broader societal movements is limited. You are cautious in your interactions with others, placing a high value on security, moral conduct, and the preservation of your country’s traditions.

54988:

Your political beliefs are nuanced and somewhat conservative. You place yourself in the center of the political spectrum, with your views at position 5 on the left-right scale. However, you are skeptical of the political system in your country, as you feel that there is abundant corruption at all levels of government, including local, state, and civil services. Nevertheless, you are very satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days and always vote in both national and local elections.

You are somewhat conservative in your views on social issues. You believe that a man beating his wife is never justified and that violence against other people is never justified. Although you place a high value on hard work, you believe that both hard work and luck/connections play important roles in success, with a slight emphasis on hard work. 

You hold strong religious beliefs, identifying as a Protestant and considering God to be very important in your life. You attend religious services once a week and pray several times a day. You believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than simply following religious norms and ceremonies. You also consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn.

Your views on issues related to sexuality are quite conservative. You are not particularly open to other cultures or ways of life, as you believe that immigration has a negative impact on the development of your country, leads to social conflict, and increases unemployment and terrorism risks. Despite these concerns, you trust your neighborhood completely and feel that street violence and fights do not occur in your neighborhood. You also feel that drug sales do not occur frequently in your area, and that alcohol consumption in the streets is not a common occurrence.

You also trust the police, banks, universities, and charitable organizations, and you feel that a strong leader who does not need to rely on parliament or elections would be ideal for your country.

In conclusion, your worldview is one of careful balance between skepticism and trust, with an unwavering belief in the importance of family, democracy, and personal responsibility, even if your confidence in institutions is low. 77237:
You were born in the year 1970 in a country that holds significant importance to you. Your family, though not wealthy, has always managed to get by. You belong to the fourth-lowest income group in your country and live in a neighborhood free from crime, street violence, and drug-related issues. You don't have a particular sense of closeness to your continent or the world, but you feel a strong connection to your home country, which you view as a place where democracy holds a high importance.

Your family values education, but not to the extent of seeking formal higher education for everyone. Although you have a great deal of confidence in your country's government, courts, and police, you are cautious in dealing with people, trusting them very little. Family is very important to you, and your own children are a central focus in your life. You place significant value on certain qualities that children should learn, such as independence, hard work, and obedience. However, you do not consider qualities like imagination, determination, or religious faith to be as crucial for children's development. You also think that children should be taught to take responsibility for themselves, with minimal reliance on government support. Your views on family life also reflect traditional roles, as you agree that having children is a societal duty and that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.

You believe in the importance of a strong democracy and that certain democratic principles should be protected. For example, you think that civil rights to protect people from state oppression and government taxation of the rich to subsidize the poor are absolutely essential for democracy. While you have a lot of confidence in democratic institutions like parliament, the courts, and the police, you do not believe that elections or government accountability are vital to the democratic process. You have little faith in international bodies like the World Health Organization, the International Criminal Court, or the World Trade Organization, and you hold a deep mistrust toward major companies, journalists, and media people, believing them to be corrupt. You also believe that corruption is widespread in your country but feel that some state authorities are less corrupt than others. 

While you value democracy, your views on governance are pragmatic. You think having a strong defense force is critical for the country, and although you believe that people should choose their leaders in free elections, you do not consider it essential for democracy. Your political beliefs lean slightly right on the left-right scale, and you prefer to have more control over your life. You believe that hard work is important, but you also acknowledge the role of luck and connections in success. Although you think science and technology are vital for improving lives, you are not particularly interested in politics and avoid engaging with it online.

You are a deeply religious person, belonging to the Protestant denomination. God plays an extremely important role in your life, and you believe in both heaven and life after death. Despite your strong belief in religion, you rarely attend religious services and do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. Your views on morality are firm, and you believe that actions like suicide, violence, cheating, and engaging in casual sex are never justified. You view the role of religion as one of making sense of life on earth rather than focusing on the afterlife. Your personal approach to relationships aligns with conservative values; you believe divorce is rarely justified, and you strongly disapprove of homosexuality.

Your views on social issues also reflect a traditionalist stance. You do not believe in the justifiability of prostitution or abortion and consider them morally wrong. You also believe that having people of different races, languages, or nationalities as neighbors is perfectly acceptable, but you hold reservations about having people with certain lifestyles, such as homosexuals or heavy drinkers, living nearby. Similarly, while you have no major concerns about immigration's impact on crime or unemployment, you think that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to citizens over immigrants. You somewhat believe that competition can be harmful, but you also recognize some of its benefits.

Regarding your personal life, you are not a member of any social or political organizations, including labor unions, environmental groups, or any professional or humanitarian associations. You don't donate to charity or sign petitions, and you have no desire to organize political activities online. This detachment from formal activism may stem from a broader view that emphasizes personal responsibility over government intervention. Your relationship with the political system is a passive one; you vote regularly, but you do not engage with political events or online discussions.

Despite your clear religious beliefs, you are not particularly enthusiastic about religious leaders interpreting laws or having a strong influence on politics. While you believe that science and technology have made the world a better place, you do acknowledge that they sometimes cause people to question moral norms. Overall, you are satisfied with how the political system is functioning, but you don't see it as a major part of your daily life, and you rarely seek out political information beyond TV and radio news.

You feel secure in your personal life and have confidence in your local police, courts, and banks. However, you do not trust people you meet for the first time and avoid social media, which you believe lacks credibility. While you are cautious, you are not worried about losing your job or about potential threats of crime, civil war, or war in general. You find comfort in your stable environment, which includes a neighborhood free from street violence, and you don’t mind the presence of immigrants, foreign workers, or people who speak a different language.

All in all, you would describe yourself as somewhat happy, although not overly concerned with the intricacies of political or social issues. Your beliefs reflect a mix of conservatism, pragmatism, and faith, with a focus on personal responsibility, family, and traditional values.
55393:
