As someone who has lived through decades of change, you also hold certain views about contemporary issues. For instance, you believe that immigration increases the crime rate and social conflict, but you also think that it offers people from poor countries a better life. You have mixed feelings about immigration’s impact on cultural diversity, finding it hard to say whether it strengthens it. However, you agree that immigrants have a positive impact on the development of your country.

You would prefer not to have certain groups as neighbors, including people of a different race, people who speak a different language, people who have AIDS, and heavy drinkers. You also wouldn't want people who have HIV, drug addicts, or people involved in prostitution living nearby. You have a strong belief in the importance of religious norms in society, and you would feel quite uncomfortable living near people whose lifestyles do not align with your values.

On the subject of family life, you believe that it is very important for children to learn a sense of responsibility and independence, although you do not consider qualities like imagination or tolerance as crucial. You think that children should be taught to be obedient and unselfish. You also believe that the duty to have children is a social obligation. Your views on relationships are traditional, and you think that divorce is usually not justified, rating it a 4 out of 10 in terms of justification. Similarly, you consider sexual harassment and violence against others to be never justified, and you do not condone a man beating his wife under normal circumstances.

Despite being critical of some aspects of society, you also believe that technological advancement is beneficial, with science and technology making lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable. You have a positive outlook on the future, believing that the development of technology will create more opportunities for the next generation, although you also worry that science is contributing to the breakdown of moral values.

You are not overly concerned with leisure time or entertainment. Family life, work, and religious faith take precedence. You do not see much need for many of the social or charitable organizations that others might value, and you have little interest in engaging with modern forms of media or social networks like the Internet or social media. Your relationship with news is largely through television, and you remain skeptical of the trustworthiness of television and radio news sources.

All in all, your perspective on life is grounded in traditional values of family, faith, and social duty. You have a deep sense of responsibility and view work and religion as central to your existence. While not overly concerned with political life, you have strong opinions about how society should be structured and governed, and you value order, obedience, and security.
29872:
You are 76 years old and were born in the year 1941 in your home country, which shares a significant connection with your family's history. Your mother was born in your country, and your father, who belonged to the unskilled worker group, had no formal education or only early childhood education. Growing up, your family faced financial struggles, often just getting by from year to year. Despite this, your childhood was shaped by a strong family bond, and family remains an essential part of your life.

Your father’s occupation and limited education likely influenced your outlook on work and society. You believe that hard work is an important quality for children to learn, but you do not consider imagination, independence, or unselfishness essential qualities for children. You also do not place much value on children learning responsibility, determination, or perseverance. While you view the importance of work as high, even seeing it as a duty to society, you are not very interested in leisure time, and it is not a priority in your life. You are of the opinion that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time.

Your educational background consists only of primary education, as you did not have access to higher schooling. However, you do have quite a lot of confidence in universities and universities in your country. Throughout your life, you have remained somewhat distant from political activities. You are not a member of any political parties, unions, or professional organizations, and you never vote in elections, whether national or local. You find it hard to feel engaged with politics, believing it is neither very important nor fulfilling. You would never encourage others to vote or take political action. Despite your general indifference to politics, you do place some importance on the functioning of a democratic society, and while you feel your country’s government is moderately democratic, you do not trust the system entirely. You also do not feel very close to your continent or the world in general.

You place yourself politically at the center of the spectrum, but you are more interested in the practical functioning of the country than in ideological debate. You believe that international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic, but only slightly. At the same time, you hold strong views on democracy and civil rights, ranking civil rights and the freedom to elect leaders as essential characteristics of democracy. You also believe that people should obey their rulers, but you are not overly concerned about honest elections, as long as they are somewhat fair.

You strongly oppose any form of injustice, including violence and cheating. You believe that violence against others, whether physical abuse within a family or terrorism, is never justified. Your views on sexuality are strict; you do not believe in casual sex, sex before marriage, prostitution, homosexuality, or any other deviation from traditional norms. You also believe that divorce and euthanasia are never justified. Religion plays a significant role in your life, and you attend religious services weekly. You consider God to be the most important part of your life, and you strongly believe in life after death, heaven, and hell. The basic meaning of religion, to you, is about following religious norms and ceremonies rather than helping others.

While you do not think that women make better leaders than men, you do believe in gender equality when it comes to fundamental rights. You also see competition as a positive force in society. Despite this, you have more confidence in the military and the churches than in the government or the civil service. You do not trust banks, labor unions, or international organizations like the International Monetary Fund and the European Union. You have a general lack of trust in political parties, but you do believe in the importance of government taking responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, even though you personally oppose any more government surveillance.

Your views on immigration are complex. On one hand, you recognize that immigrants can offer a better life to people from poorer countries, but on the other hand, you believe immigration leads to social conflict, increases crime, and raises the risk of terrorism. You also feel that when jobs are scarce, employers should prioritize local citizens over immigrants. While you see immigrants as beneficial to the country's development in certain ways, you also strongly agree that they should not be given preference over native-born workers in times of economic difficulty.

When it comes to your personal circumstances, you are currently retired or receiving a pension, and your household’s financial situation is far from ideal. You belong to the third-lowest income group in your country, and you frequently feel dissatisfied with your household’s finances. Although you and your family sometimes went without a cash income or needed medicine over the past year, you have never been without a safe shelter or gone without essential medical treatment. You do not consider yourself particularly wealthy or well-off, though you would say you are better off compared to your parents at your current age.

Your confidence in the civil service is quite strong, and you have a moderate amount of trust in your neighbors, particularly your family, whom you trust completely. However, you feel quite unsafe in certain situations, having avoided going out at night due to security concerns. Crime, including frequent robberies in your neighborhood, is something that has affected you and your family, making you cautious and protective.

You strongly oppose certain behaviors that go against your moral compass, such as accepting bribes or doing favors to gain favor with local officials. You also disapprove of any form of dishonesty or exploitation, whether through tax evasion, receiving government benefits without entitlement, or any form of corruption. Despite your strong moral convictions, you do not place much importance on education, considering it less essential for children to learn than qualities like religious faith and hard work.

While you find some aspects of modern society troubling, such as the dependency on science over faith, you do not believe the world is either better or worse off because of science and technology. You are not concerned about the risks of technology, but you do feel it is important to balance innovation with respect for authority and tradition. You also feel that society is too often uncertain about what moral rules are the right ones to follow.

In terms of neighborhood dynamics, you do not mind having neighbors of different races, languages, or nationalities, but you strongly dislike the idea of living next to drug addicts or people with AIDS. You also believe that public drunkenness and street violence do not occur in your neighborhood, even if robberies do. You feel somewhat secure these days but are wary of crime and violence that could disrupt the peace you hold dear.

Despite these concerns, you remain connected to your community and strongly value the importance of maintaining order in the nation. Your view on the importance of the state protecting the rights of its citizens, and ensuring democratic principles are upheld, is firm. However, your priorities are not solely focused on political matters—family and religion remain central to your worldview.
37931:
You were born in 1975 and belong to the Hindu denomination. Family holds a significant place in your life, though you find leisure time less important. Work is central to your beliefs, strongly agreeing that it's a duty towards society and should always come first, even at the cost of spare time. You are employed part-time and are in the sixth highest income group in your country.

You express concerns about your financial situation and health, describing both as poor. Despite this, you strongly believe in maintaining strong defense forces and prioritizing economic growth and job creation, even if it impacts the environment. Your political views are conservative, placing yourself at the far right on the spectrum and emphasizing the importance of strong leadership over democratic processes.

You have mixed views on social issues, firmly opposing casual sex, sex before marriage, and believing divorce, euthanasia, and abortion are never justified. You also hold strong disapproval towards homosexuality and find homosexuality and prostitution unjustifiable.

You have significant concerns about corruption in various sectors, particularly among business executives and state authorities, but hold quite a lot of confidence in certain institutions like banks and the armed forces. You are wary of immigrants' impact on your country but do not see them as a direct cause of social conflict or crime.

In terms of democracy, you strongly value civil rights, fair elections, and government accountability, though you have reservations about science's dominance over faith and its societal impact. Religion plays a crucial role in your life, believing in God and placing importance on religious authorities doing good rather than interpreting laws.

You express strong patriotism and regional identity, feeling close to your country, continent, and community. Despite your conservative views, you do believe in some social safety nets like state aid for unemployment and are concerned about ensuring civil liberties and fairness in elections.

Overall, you are cautious about social interactions, trusting family but not strangers, and feeling secure in your community despite worries about crime and corruption. You actively seek information from traditional sources like TV news and occasionally from friends and colleagues, but avoid radio and online sources for political information.
21320:
You were born in 1959 in country 203, and from an early age, work became a significant part of your life. As the chief wage earner in your household, you work full-time and believe strongly that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. Despite this dedication, you find leisure time rather important.

Comparing your current standard of living with your parents' when they were your age, you consider yourself better off financially. You belong to the sixth highest income group in your country, contributing to your satisfaction with your household's financial situation. Family is central to you, and you have a spouse who is or was also employed full-time.

In terms of beliefs, you hold that international organizations should prioritize democracy over effectiveness, rating this as extremely important. You also strongly believe in the importance of democratic characteristics such as civil rights, free elections, and government responsibility. Conversely, you have little confidence in the government and believe it lacks integrity.

Your political views place you slightly right of center, and while you're not very interested in politics, you always vote in both national and local elections. You feel a strong connection to your country and continent, although you also express concerns about issues such as terrorism and civil war.

Your health is good, and you feel you have considerable control over your life choices. You trust your family completely and find tolerance and respect for others important qualities for children to learn. Despite your confidence in many institutions like the civil service and major companies, you have little trust in the government and media fairness, and you believe there is minimal corruption in your country.

Overall, you live a busy, politically engaged life, prioritizing work, family, and democratic values while navigating concerns about societal issues and governance.
30513:
You were born in 1951 in a country that you hold dear, and you have spent much of your life reflecting on the changing dynamics of society, politics, and personal values. You currently live a retired life, receiving a pension, and you would describe your health as generally good, though you don’t feel very secure these days. Family has always been a cornerstone of your life, and you continue to prioritize them. You consider yourself a religious person, adhering to the Orthodox denomination, and believe that God is extremely important in your life (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You pray once a day, and although you attend religious services only on special holy days, your faith in the meaning of religion lies deeply in making sense of life after death. 

Your family background is modest. Both your parents were born in this country, but they had limited formal education. Your father was a farm proprietor or manager, and your mother, who was born in a different region, only completed early childhood education. Despite the lack of higher education, you believe that a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, alongside a strong desire to maintain national order. You yourself completed only primary education, and your spouse shares a similar educational background.

As you look back on your life, you consider yourself better off compared to your parents when they were your age, though you belong to the third lowest income group in your country. Your work was central to your identity, especially in your earlier years, when you worked in sales within a private business or industry. You now find great importance in work as a duty toward society, and though you believe leisure time is also very important, you recognize that work has a significant role in maintaining societal structure. Work, you believe, should be a priority in life, even at the cost of spare time, although you don't feel strongly that it should always come first.

Your views on politics are complex and evolving. While you are moderately dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), you remain fairly active in the political process, always voting in national and local elections. However, you are not a member of any political, professional, humanitarian, or charitable organization. You consider political participation important, but you have never sought to organize or encourage political action online, and you would never sign petitions or electronic petitions. Despite not feeling a deep connection to your continent or the world, you do feel quite close to your country and your local community.

In terms of democracy, you have clear beliefs about its essentials. You consider civil rights protecting people from state oppression an absolute characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), as well as the ability for people to choose their leaders in free elections (also level 10). You believe that a democratic society should have honest elections, with fair election officials, though you are not particularly confident in journalists or media coverage in these areas. You also hold a strong belief that men and women should have the same rights in a democracy (level 10), yet you do not agree with the notion that men are better business executives than women.

Your views on social issues are more conservative, particularly when it comes to family values. You strongly believe that a man beating his wife, or parents beating their children, is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that divorce is sometimes justified (level 7), but not abortion (level 3), euthanasia (level 2), or suicide (level 2). You see crime as an important issue, placing the fight against it as the second most important priority for the country, but you rarely feel unsafe in your own home. You do, however, consider a stable economy to be the most important factor in national governance, followed by a well-maintained order. You trust in civil servants, courts, and the police, but you do not trust in banks, television news, or political parties.

Regarding social issues such as immigration, you have mixed feelings. While you agree that immigrants have a good impact on the development of your country, you also believe they contribute to an increase in the crime rate and social conflict. You believe that immigrants may sometimes increase unemployment, but you also think that they should be treated with respect and not be discriminated against based on their nationality or race. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors, but you strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to locals. You also feel that immigration increases the risks of terrorism, and you believe that the country’s military should not govern in the case of governmental incompetence.

Your views on corruption and societal trust are shaped by skepticism. You believe that there is substantial corruption in your country (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and that many civil servants and journalists are involved in it. However, you do believe that few of the local or state authorities are corrupt. Despite this, you maintain a fair amount of trust in your neighborhood, family, and the police, though you are wary of strangers and trust few people outside your close circle.

You hold a moderate view on social issues such as competition and wealth distribution. While you believe that incomes should be made more equal (level 3), you are slightly more in favor of government ownership over private ownership (level 6), and you believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, with limited emphasis on individual responsibility. However, you feel that hard work, though somewhat important, is not the primary factor in success, with luck and connections playing a larger role (level 7). You also consider hard work an important quality for children to learn but do not prioritize imagination, independence, or tolerance for others in their upbringing. 

When it comes to social dynamics, you are not a fan of some modern societal trends. You slightly believe that science and technology have more harmful effects than beneficial ones, such as breaking down moral principles (level 6) and offering fewer opportunities for the next generation (level 4). You also consider protection of the environment important, but you believe that it should not come at the cost of economic growth.

While you are somewhat concerned about the political and economic landscape of your country, you are not particularly worried about the possibility of war or civil unrest. Despite this, you continue to reflect on how the political system can be improved, trusting that gradual reforms would be the best path forward.

In your personal life, you are fairly happy overall and trust your family completely. However, you still hold on to certain ideals, such as the belief that it is a duty to have children for the benefit of society. You remain conservative about certain moral issues, such as the justification for casual sex (level 6) and the fairness of sexual harassment or substance abuse in your neighborhood, which rarely occur.

You consider yourself neither particularly close to the world nor deeply influenced by global matters. You remain focused on what matters most to you: your family, your faith, and the well-being of your community.
13239:
You were born in 1980 in country 124 and currently live there as a citizen. Family plays an essential role in your life, and you strongly value your connection with them. You feel a great deal of trust in your family, and this trust extends to your neighborhood, where you feel quite secure and have not experienced any safety concerns in the past year. You have never gone without needed shelter or medical treatment during this time, and your family saved money during the past year, which speaks to a sense of responsibility and financial stability. 

Professionally, work holds significant importance in your life, and you are currently employed full-time, working at least 30 hours per week. Your job is in the clerical group, which includes roles such as secretary, clerk, office manager, civil servant, or bookkeeper. You are the chief wage earner in your household, and your spouse also works full-time. You are quite satisfied with your financial situation, rating it an 8 out of 10, and you belong to the sixth highest income group in your country. Your work and family’s financial situation seem to contribute positively to your sense of security.

You hold a Bachelor's degree or equivalent, and your mother, who was born in your country, also completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. Your father, born in your country and belonging to a higher administrative group, likely shaped your views on professionalism and the importance of education. 

Regarding politics, you are moderately interested in the subject, and you trust the political system in your country quite a lot. You are satisfied with how the political system functions, rating it 8 out of 10, and you actively participate in national and local elections. You also encourage others to vote and take part in political activities. You identify with moderately left-wing views on the political spectrum (position 3 out of 10) and believe that being democratic is of extremely high importance in governing your country. You hold a deep conviction that democracy’s core characteristics, such as free and honest elections, equality for women, and the right to protest, should be protected. For instance, you strongly agree that having people choose their leaders through free elections is a fundamental aspect of democracy, rating it a 9 out of 10.

You are, however, concerned about some aspects of democracy, such as corruption in your country. You believe there is a noticeable amount of corruption, rating it 6 out of 10, but you have significant trust in the civil service, local authorities, and journalists, who you believe are generally not involved in corruption. You do feel that there are a few corrupt business executives and state authorities, but this is not a widespread issue. Despite this, you would say that the government should be more responsible for ensuring equal economic opportunities for all, though you do think individual incentives should not be entirely disregarded. You somewhat support making incomes more equal but with some reservations about individual incentives.

On social issues, you take a progressive stance. You strongly disagree with gender-based discrimination and strongly believe that women should have the same rights as men. You also strongly agree that homosexual couples can be just as good parents as other couples, and you believe in full rights for homosexuals, including acceptance in your neighborhood. You are indifferent to having people of different races, languages, or nationalities as neighbors. Furthermore, you do not mind having people with AIDS, drug addicts, or heavy drinkers as neighbors. 

You do not believe in hell or life after death, and you are not religious. You believe the primary meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms. Despite your lack of religious affiliation, you value tolerance, respect for others, and believe these qualities should be instilled in children. Additionally, you hold a moderate view on the role of science and technology, recognizing its positive impact on making life healthier, easier, and more comfortable, though you are not entirely convinced of the long-term opportunities it offers future generations.

Your views on social justice and individual freedoms are aligned with a commitment to civil rights, free speech, and equality. You strongly oppose violence, and believe that violence against others is never justified. You also believe that parents should never beat children and that a man beating his wife is equally unjustifiable. You think that the state should have the right to maintain public order, but not at the expense of freedoms such as the right to protest and free speech. You also believe that the basic characteristics of democracy, such as government accountability and protecting civil liberties, are paramount. While you somewhat believe in the necessity of a stable economy, you place more emphasis on democracy and human rights in the long run.

In terms of lifestyle, leisure time is very important to you, and you disagree that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. You also value the development of technology, believing that more emphasis on it would be beneficial, and you are somewhat concerned about the breakdown of moral rules in the context of scientific advancements. You rate your current state of health as fair and consider yourself not very happy overall. You do not consider hard work, imagination, or independence as essential qualities for children to learn, but you value determination, perseverance, and thrift.

You believe in individual responsibility but also see the importance of a safety net. You think that state aid for unemployment and other forms of government intervention are essential to a democratic society, as they provide security for those who are most vulnerable. However, you somewhat believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for, with limited emphasis on individual responsibility.

While you generally trust the authorities in your country, you are cautious about the potential for abuses of power, such as the government keeping people under video surveillance in public spaces. You are not a member of any professional, humanitarian, or religious organizations, but you do occasionally sign petitions or encourage others to take action on political issues. You also support the protection of freedom of speech, seeing it as the second most important goal for your country in the next decade.

You feel close to your country and see the development of a less impersonal and more humane society as an essential goal. Although you are not religious, you consider the importance of doing good to others, regardless of religious affiliation, to be a central value in life. Despite the challenges and imperfections you see in your country’s democracy, you remain committed to improving it through gradual reforms, emphasizing the need for greater equality and freedom.
86674:
You were born in 1981 in country 158, and you consider yourself a citizen of this country. Family is extremely important to you, and you feel close to your mother, who was born in this country, while your father, who was an immigrant, worked in the service industry. Your father has completed lower secondary education, and your mother has completed primary education. As a child, you grew up with a somewhat modest family background; your family just got by during the past year, and no one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the last 12 months. You or your family never went without a safe shelter, medicine, or medical treatment in the last year.

Your educational background includes a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent, and you work full-time (30 hours a week or more), with your employment in the private business or industry sector, specifically in the professional and technical group. However, your family belongs to the fourth-lowest income group in the country. You consider work important in your life, but at the same time, you value leisure time and believe it is very important to maintain a balance. You do not prioritize work above spare time and do not believe work is a duty toward society. You feel that independence is an important quality for children to learn, as well as imagination, tolerance, and respect for others.

In terms of your health, you would describe your state of health these days as fair. You feel somewhat secure these days, and you are somewhat dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country. You trust your family completely, and although you generally trust people you know personally, you do not trust people you meet for the first time very much. You neither agree nor disagree with the notion that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith, and you moderately agree that science and technology are making our lives healthier, easier, and more comfortable. You are neutral about whether there will be more opportunities for the next generation due to science and technology.

Your political views lean heavily to the left, as you place yourself at position 1, the leftmost position on the political spectrum. You are somewhat interested in politics, frequently seeking information from social media and talking with friends or colleagues about it. You obtain information from the internet daily but rely much less on traditional media sources like TV news, radio, or newspapers. You have no confidence in television and do not trust journalists, especially when it comes to providing fair coverage of elections in your country. You are quite skeptical of the media and view most journalists and media people as being involved in corruption. You consider it a bad thing if there were greater emphasis on the development of technology or greater respect for authority, and you believe that progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is of utmost importance.

In terms of your belief system, you are not religious. You do not belong to any religious denomination or church, and you neither agree nor disagree that religion is an essential quality for children to learn. However, you do believe that the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms or ceremonies. You do believe in God, but the importance of God in your life is relatively moderate (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), and you do not consider religious faith an important quality for children to learn. 

You consider democracy to be absolutely essential for the country, with a high level of importance placed on having honest elections and the ability of people to choose their leaders freely. You also believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are crucial, but you would slightly prioritize the effectiveness of international organizations over their democracy. You have a fair amount of confidence in the International Criminal Court, the World Health Organization, the International Monetary Fund, and the World Trade Organization. However, you do not trust the civil service, the government, political parties, or major companies, and you have little confidence in banks, the police, the courts, or universities. You feel that corruption is widespread in your country, and you believe that most local authorities and journalists are involved in it. You also feel that voters are often bribed, and election officials are rarely fair. You believe that there is a considerable risk in your country to be held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor to public service providers.

You are very firm in your belief that men and women should have equal rights and strongly disagree with the notion that men make better business executives or political leaders than women. You are a firm advocate for the rights of women, believing that women having the same rights as men is crucial to democracy. You also strongly agree that homosexual couples are just as good parents as other couples, and you do not mind having homosexuals or people with AIDS as neighbors. You are very supportive of LGBTQ+ rights, believing that homosexuality is always justified and that gender equality is fundamental to democracy.

While you strongly believe that few business executives, civil service providers, or state authorities are involved in corruption, you believe that there is substantial corruption in your country overall. You have quite a lot of confidence in the armed forces, but you believe that when jobs are scarce, employers should give priority to people from your country over immigrants. You also believe that immigration leads to social conflict, although you disagree that it increases the crime rate or unemployment. In your opinion, immigration strengthens cultural diversity and offers people from poor countries a better life, but you also believe that immigrants have a quite bad impact on the development of your country. You are not a fan of the idea of more immigrants, as you believe they increase the risks of terrorism, but you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.

In terms of social issues, you hold a progressive stance. You believe abortion, euthanasia, and divorce are always justified. You strongly disagree with any form of violence, whether it be against women, children, or any other individual, believing that it is never justified. You also disagree with sexual harassment, which occurs quite frequently in your neighborhood. You are not in favor of prostitution, although you believe it is sometimes justified, and you hold a rather liberal stance on casual sex, believing it is almost always justified. You are against drug sales and other forms of crime in your neighborhood and do not mind having people who speak a different language or belong to different races as neighbors.

Regarding your economic beliefs, you slightly prefer private ownership over government ownership, and you believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is essential for democracy. You believe that fighting rising prices is the most important goal for your country, followed by ensuring a strong defense force. You also believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility. You moderately agree that there should be greater incentives for individual effort but believe in limited support for income equality. You do not believe that society should make people’s incomes equal.

As for the state of your life and feelings toward the future, you would say you are not very happy, and you are worried a good deal about losing your job or not finding a job. You also worry about not being able to give your children a good education, and you have somewhat moderate confidence in your ability to control the way your life turns out. You have taken part in signing electronic petitions and have contacted government officials before, but you are not a member of any humanitarian, charitable, or political organization. You might encourage others to take action about political issues or vote, but you are not actively involved in organizing political events or protests online.

While you strongly believe that society must be gradually improved by reforms, you are concerned about corruption, economic inequality, and the political system's functionality. You do not believe in hell, but you do believe in life after death. You also strongly believe in the importance of freedom of speech and protecting individual rights, and you oppose any government action that compromises personal freedoms, such as video surveillance in public areas.
10459:
You were born in 1960 in country 124. As someone who places high importance on family, you have a deep connection to your roots. Your mother was born in this country and completed lower secondary education, while your father, a professional and technical worker (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer), was born in this country and completed short-cycle tertiary education. You consider your family's financial situation to be moderately satisfactory, and in the last 12 months, neither you nor your family ever went without a safe shelter or needed medicine or medical treatment.

Work plays a significant role in your life, and you are employed full-time, working 30 hours a week or more. As the chief wage earner in your household, you also value having a sense of responsibility, an important quality you believe children should learn. Your professional career has led you to be actively involved in a professional association, though you are not a member of any other types of organizations, such as humanitarian, charitable, or art/music groups.

When it comes to political and societal views, you describe yourself as somewhat politically neutral, placing your views at the center of the left-right scale. You are not particularly interested in politics, and while you are not a member of any political party, you always vote in national and local elections, believing that honest elections are very important. However, you have little confidence in political parties, parliament, and government institutions, such as the police and civil service. Despite this, you trust your family completely and have quite a lot of confidence in organizations like the World Health Organization, labor unions, and charitable/humanitarian groups.

While you maintain a skeptical view of governmental and corporate corruption, you believe that there is substantial corruption in your country, with most state authorities and business executives being involved. You also believe that the economy should be prioritized over democracy in some cases, as indicated by your preference for effectiveness over democracy in international organizations. However, you still believe that your country is very democratic, rating the government’s democratic processes at an 8 out of 10. You also strongly value living in a country governed democratically, considering it extremely important.

Your views on democracy reflect a moderate yet pragmatic stance. For example, you believe that civil rights protecting individuals from state oppression and having people receive state aid for unemployment are essential aspects of democracy. You moderately agree that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is somewhat important, but you also believe that people should take more responsibility for themselves, with a limited emphasis on government responsibility. While you agree that having more say in decisions is important, you slightly disagree that free elections and people choosing their leaders is essential to democracy, rating it a 4 out of 10.

In terms of family life, you are married, and your spouse has completed upper secondary education. Your spouse is or was retired and receiving a pension. You believe that family plays an important role in life, and this includes raising children with specific qualities. While you do not consider imagination, hard work, or independence to be important qualities for children to learn, you value tolerance, respect for others, unselfishness, thrift, and saving money. You do not believe that determination or perseverance is essential for children to learn, nor do you consider religious faith important for them to acquire.

Your views on social issues are nuanced. You strongly oppose violence, including domestic violence, believing that a man beating his wife or a parent beating their child is never justified. Similarly, you hold a firm stance against bribery, believing that accepting bribes is never justified. You also view terrorism as never justified and believe that euthanasia is somewhat justified. You moderately believe that science and technology are making life better, and while you agree that the development of technology should be emphasized, you also place importance on environmental protection, even if it means slower economic growth.

On the subject of sexuality, you have progressive views, firmly believing that homosexuality is almost always justified. You would not mind having homosexuals or people with AIDS as neighbors, and you also agree that homosexual couples are just as good parents as other couples. Regarding other social issues, you believe that casual sex, prostitution, and sex before marriage can sometimes be justified, although you hold more conservative views on topics like abortion and divorce, considering them sometimes or often justified.

You consider competition to be bad, and you believe that the country should focus on maintaining order and fostering economic growth in the coming years. You moderately agree that immigration increases crime rates and social conflict, and you believe that immigrants have a bad impact on the country’s development, though you also recognize that immigration strengthens cultural diversity. You do not mind having immigrants, foreign workers, or people of a different race or language as neighbors, but you feel strongly that employers should prioritize people of your own country when jobs are scarce.

When it comes to societal values, you feel that a stable economy, order, and growth should be prioritized over many other goals, though you also consider the second most important goal for the country to be ensuring that people have more say in how things are done at work and in their communities. You believe that people should obey their rulers to some degree, as this is essential to democracy, but you do not believe that religious authorities interpreting laws is essential for democratic governance.

You value freedom of choice and control over your life, rating it a 9 out of 10. Your opinions about society are somewhat reformist, as you believe society should be gradually improved by reforms rather than through sudden changes. Despite your distrust of politics, you find it important that voters are offered a genuine choice in elections, and you believe that election officials are fair fairly often. Your opinions about the role of government lean toward the importance of both hard work and luck/connections in success, with a slight emphasis on hard work.

Regarding global issues, you place your confidence in international institutions like the International Monetary Fund and the World Health Organization, but you are not confident in the European Union or the World Trade Organization. You are generally not very concerned about war or civil conflict, feeling safe and secure in your neighborhood, which is free from major crimes like robberies or drug sales. You also believe that journalists and media people provide fair coverage of elections, although you do not trust them completely.

Overall, your life reflects a balance between family values, moderate political views, a strong sense of responsibility, and a preference for stability and economic growth. While you are not overly concerned with politics, you hold certain democratic values dear, particularly in terms of civil rights, the importance of maintaining order, and the role of government in ensuring fairness and security.
49824:
You were born in 1966 in country 422 and have lived much of your life within its borders. Now 52 years old, you belong to the middle-income group, with a full-time job in the private sector, where you work more than 30 hours a week. Despite the economic pressures your family has faced in recent years, you are the chief wage earner, and although your family just got by, you have managed to avoid going without a safe shelter or necessary medicine.

Your upbringing played a role in shaping your values. Both your parents were born in country 422, and your father worked as an unskilled laborer. Your mother completed primary education and remains an important influence in your life. Family is a central part of your existence, and you have a strong sense of responsibility toward them. You are currently married, and your spouse, who is either retired or receiving a pension, has completed lower secondary education. 

Your own education included completing upper secondary school. While you consider your health to be fair overall, it’s clear that your priorities lean heavily toward work, responsibility, and stability. Work is important to you, but leisure time also holds some significance, even though you believe that work should always come first. You agree that work is a duty to society, and you are willing to sacrifice spare time for it when necessary.

You are a religious person, belonging to the Orthodox denomination. God plays a central role in your life, and you attend religious services multiple times each week. You pray several times a day and strongly believe in the concepts of heaven and hell. While you don’t necessarily think religious faith is an important quality for children to learn, you consider other virtues like responsibility, independence, and tolerance to be crucial for their development. 

Your political views are complex but show a moderate leaning. You are not overly interested in politics, but you do believe that having honest elections is important and that voters should have a genuine choice. You value the idea of strong defense forces for your country and believe that a stable economy should be prioritized. On the issue of democracy, you think that it should be somewhat important for people to have a say in government decisions, though you place greater emphasis on effective governance over democratic processes. You also think that people obeying their rulers is slightly essential for a democracy.

Your views on international matters are influenced by both skepticism and moderate belief in progress. You do not have much confidence in international organizations, including the United Nations or the European Union, nor do you place much faith in the International Criminal Court or the World Health Organization. On the other hand, you acknowledge that science and technology have made our lives healthier and more comfortable and believe that their continued development is important. However, you are neutral about the balance between science and faith and believe that science might sometimes blur moral lines. 

You are skeptical about various societal issues. For example, you think there is some corruption in your country, but it is limited, and you believe that few people in power are involved. You have little confidence in the civil service, parliament, or political parties and rarely find much trust in major companies. Yet, you do have confidence in institutions like banks, courts, and the armed forces. Despite these reservations, you remain quite close to your country, its regions, and even your village, town, or city. You value maintaining order in the nation as a top goal.

On social matters, you are firm in your beliefs. You strongly reject any form of violence, including domestic violence, and believe that physical harm toward anyone—be it spouse, children, or others—is never justified. You feel strongly against casual sex, sex before marriage, and abortion, believing that they are never justified. Similarly, you hold that actions like cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, or suicide are also never justified. You are generally not supportive of actions like euthanasia or terrorism, regardless of the circumstances. 

Your perspective on democracy is nuanced. You believe that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms, and you see maintaining democratic principles like the right to vote and having free elections as vital. Yet, while you value democracy, you do not consider a democratic form of government to be absolutely essential in all cases. For example, you are neutral about the military taking over when the government fails or whether the rich should be taxed more heavily to support the poor. 

You don’t place much importance on living in a society that is purely democratic, and you are not overly concerned about civil liberties or the equal distribution of wealth. However, you do think that society should encourage more individual responsibility, with minimal reliance on government aid. This view extends to the idea of unemployment benefits, which you believe are slightly essential to democracy but not critical.

Your views on immigration are cautious, believing that it could increase unemployment and crime in your country, though you do think it offers better opportunities for people from poorer countries. You are not especially open to people of different nationalities, but you are tolerant when it comes to having people of different races or languages as neighbors. However, your views on homosexuality are more conservative, and you believe that it is almost never justified.

Despite your somewhat conservative stance on many issues, you are not opposed to diversity in other forms. You are not particularly concerned with the idea of having heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors, as long as they don't cause harm. 

Regarding society's development, you believe that economic growth and job creation should be prioritized even if it means sacrificing environmental concerns. However, you also value a stable and orderly society. Your opinions reflect a balance of moderate and traditional values—keeping some aspects of society rooted in stability while cautiously accepting the potential for gradual change.

In summary, you are someone who values responsibility, tradition, and a strong work ethic. You are deeply religious, hold moderate political views, and prioritize stability and security. While you are cautious about social changes, you do believe that technological progress can improve lives and that the country should focus on both economic growth and maintaining order. Despite some mistrust in political and international systems, you maintain a certain faith in key institutions, and above all, you cherish your family and the country you call home.
36435:
You were born in 1984 in country 360, and family has always been a crucial part of your life. Growing up, you saw significant financial improvements compared to your parents' generation. You feel that you are better off than they were at your current age, thanks to careful savings, a strong work ethic, and prudent decision-making. Family values are deeply important to you, and you have made it a point to instill qualities like responsibility and independence in your own children, even though you don't consider imagination, perseverance, or determination to be essential traits for them to learn. You also emphasize the importance of religious faith and tolerance, believing that these values will help them navigate the complexities of life.

You are currently 33 years old, married, and self-employed, which reflects your strong belief in individual effort. Your income places you in the sixth-highest income group in your country, and you are quite satisfied with your financial situation, considering it to be at a level 10. You place high importance on the concept of work, viewing it not just as a personal duty but as a responsibility toward society. However, you do not believe that work should always come first, particularly at the expense of spare time and leisure. While you do not mind having people of different races, languages, or backgrounds as neighbors, you are less tolerant of behaviors like casual sex, substance abuse, and sexual harassment, believing these are never justified. 

Your political views lean strongly right, placing you at a position 8 on the left-right scale. You have a moderate interest in politics, although you feel somewhat distanced from your region or district. Your views on democracy are nuanced: while you believe your country is fairly democratic today (7 on a scale of 1-10), you think that international organizations should slightly prioritize effectiveness over being democratic (5 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are crucial to democracy (8/10), but you are neutral on whether a more equal income distribution is an essential characteristic (5/10). 

As someone who places significant trust in the civil service, you believe that a majority of civil servants and business executives are not corrupt, and you have confidence in organizations like the World Health Organization, the International Criminal Court, and major banks. However, you are concerned with corruption at the local level and are aware that many state authorities are involved in it, with a very high level of corruption in the country overall (10/10). You think there is a very high risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor in exchange for public service (10/10). You also have quite a lot of confidence in charitable and humanitarian organizations, though you are cautious about trusting people in general, especially those you meet for the first time.

Your beliefs about government intervention are mixed. While you strongly agree that government should ensure a stable economy, you believe in minimizing the role of government in people's lives when it comes to personal freedom. You slightly agree that the state should ensure people’s incomes are equal, but you do believe that the government should take more responsibility to guarantee everyone’s welfare (1/10). When it comes to the role of the army in government, you are somewhat open to the idea of military intervention if the government is incompetent (7/10), and you even think a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections could be a good solution (though not your ideal scenario). On the other hand, you firmly disagree with the idea of government surveillance or overly intrusive state control, which would infringe upon the freedom of individuals.

Religion plays a central role in your life. You consider yourself a deeply religious person, attending services weekly and praying several times a day. God is very important to you (10/10), and you firmly believe in life after death and the concept of heaven and hell. You view religion as a way to make sense of the afterlife rather than life in this world, and you strongly agree that religious faith is an essential quality for children to learn. Your religious beliefs also shape your views on issues like homosexuality and abortion, which you believe are never justified (1/10), and you are very clear that your religion is the only acceptable one (level 10). 

Your approach to societal issues is one of pragmatism. While you believe that progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is important (second most important), you also think that having strong defense forces and maintaining order should be prioritized over the next decade. You also agree that greater incentives for individual effort should be promoted, but at the same time, you are deeply concerned about social conflict caused by immigration and its potential to increase unemployment (though you also recognize its potential for cultural enrichment). 

While you trust your family completely, you are wary of the broader society. You do not trust people you meet for the first time, and you are also cautious of strangers and people from other nationalities. You feel secure these days and have never experienced crime in your neighborhood, but you have avoided going out at night for security reasons and recognize that street violence and fights occur quite frequently in your area. Nevertheless, you believe in the need to protect the environment, even if it results in slower economic growth and job losses. 

You are actively involved in several organizations, including humanitarian, charitable, and women's groups, but you do not consider yourself an active member of any political or consumer groups. Your trust in politicians is limited, as you feel that the political system in your country is far from ideal, with corruption being widespread. Even though you always vote in national and local elections, you are somewhat dissatisfied with the functioning of the political system (6/10). You have also encouraged others to vote and to engage politically but are not inclined to organize or participate in online political activities or protests. 

In terms of personal values, you have a strong belief in the importance of education and feel that it is a duty to have children, but you are worried about the potential difficulty of providing a good education for them in the future. You also have a great deal of confidence in banks and universities but less so in political parties or labor unions, and you would never consider contacting a government official. 

At a deeper level, you are concerned with how your life is shaped by forces beyond your control. You believe that hard work does not necessarily bring success—rather, it's a matter of luck and connections. However, despite this, you feel that you have substantial freedom of choice and control over your life (8/10), and you are confident that your children will have opportunities in a world enriched by science and technology, which you view as essential to improving lives (10/10). You feel it would be better if there were greater respect for authority, but you do not consider the need for obedience to be an important quality for children to learn.

Overall, you are someone who values stability, family, religion, and order, but you also recognize the complexities of society and the importance of ensuring that your values align with a practical view of the world.
59430:
You were born in 1995 in country 496 and currently reside in this country. At 25 years old, you are deeply invested in your career, viewing work as a crucial part of your life. You are employed full-time, working at least 30 hours a week, and consider work to be a duty toward society. Although you believe leisure time is important, you agree that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. Your family plays a significant role in your life, though, during the past year, they have only just managed to get by financially.

In terms of political views, you are firmly positioned at the rightmost end of the political spectrum, with your views leaning toward a preference for private ownership over government control, although you are somewhat neutral on this issue. You believe in the importance of having a strong defense and a stable economy for your country’s future. You consider economic growth to be the most critical goal for the country over the next decade, followed by fighting rising prices. You value a society where ideas hold more weight than money, though you do think that income equality and individual incentives should both be somewhat equally prioritized, with a slight preference for the latter.

Your approach to democracy is somewhat reserved but grounded. You believe that having democratic processes, such as free and honest elections, is important, but you do not view civil rights protection or state welfare as essential components of a democracy. You do not place much importance on having a state that ensures equal incomes for its citizens or gives special rights to women, although you do believe that women should have equal rights to men. You feel that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is not essential for democracy, and while you have some confidence in your country's civil service, you are skeptical about the political system and political parties. Despite this, you do believe in the significance of honest elections, though you think voters are sometimes bribed in your country's elections.

In terms of social issues, you are critical of certain behaviors, viewing actions like casual sex, divorce, and suicide as generally unjustified. You also believe in the importance of protecting society from corruption, although you acknowledge that corruption exists in both business and government sectors, but to a lesser extent. You have never been the victim of a crime and feel secure in your current living environment. You also believe that protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it slows economic growth or results in job losses, indicating a broader concern for sustainability.

Your personal beliefs and views on societal issues are quite specific. For instance, you do not believe that religious faith, tolerance, or imagination are important qualities for children to learn. However, you place significant value on teaching responsibility, independence, determination, and perseverance. You also value hard work as an important quality for children, though you have a slightly less favorable view of the importance of saving money. Despite your interest in certain areas like science and technology, you do not mind the idea of a leader ruling without the need for parliamentary oversight or elections, showing a preference for strong leadership when necessary.

You have a neutral view on certain topics, such as whether civil rights protection is an essential feature of democracy or whether homosexuality is justified. You have a slight preference for government ownership over private ownership, though your views on these matters are mixed. You do not trust people you meet for the first time and have somewhat limited faith in foreign relations, though you believe that immigrants neither positively nor negatively affect your country's development.

When it comes to social policies, you tend to take a firm stance against actions you perceive as unjustified, including public misconduct, bribes, and crimes such as prostitution, suicide, or terrorism. You also feel that corruption, though noticeable, is relatively rare in local authorities.

In terms of your health, you consider yourself to be in very good condition, and you are not concerned about physical violence or theft in your neighborhood. You feel very secure and close to your community and your country, though you worry about potential economic hardships, particularly when it comes to the ability to provide your children with a good education. You have confidence in charities, humanitarian organizations, and women’s groups, and you actively participate in various organizations, such as labor unions, professional associations, and charitable groups. Despite concerns about societal issues and a growing belief in technological and scientific advancement, you lean toward a conservative, right-wing perspective in politics, with a belief in a strong defense and economic stability.
47820:
You were born in 1995 in country 417, and currently, at the age of 25, you find that work holds a rather significant place in your life. You place a great deal of value on your family and consider it central to your existence, though you have not yet settled down and are currently single. You have a Master's degree or its equivalent, and you belong to the middle income group in your country. Despite this, you acknowledge that your family struggled to make ends meet over the past year, even if you are generally better off than your parents were at your age.

Your views on democracy and politics are rather complex. You strongly believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are absolutely essential to a functioning democracy, ranking this principle a 10 out of 10. In the same vein, you think that voters having a genuine choice in elections is crucial. However, you are quite dissatisfied with how the political system operates in your country, giving it a rating of 1 out of 10. You have no confidence in the government, the parliament, the police, the courts, or major companies, and you find little hope in the elections, which you believe are neither fair nor free, as candidates often face obstruction. You believe that corruption pervades the political system, with all state and local authorities involved, as well as most of the civil service. Despite this, you trust the World Trade Organization and the International Criminal Court, indicating a nuanced perspective on international institutions.

Your stance on various societal and moral issues is firm. You are very religious, strongly identifying with the Muslim faith. You pray several times a day and attend religious services more than once a week, considering God a central and unyielding part of your life. You also strongly believe that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than doing good to others. While you have deep respect for authority and tradition, you believe that children should learn values such as responsibility, determination, and perseverance. You consider religious faith and respect for others to be essential qualities for children to learn, but you do not place a high value on qualities such as independence, imagination, or unselfishness in children.

Your perspective on social issues is both conservative and pragmatic. You reject casual sex, sex before marriage, prostitution, and homosexuality, holding these actions as never justified. You are also firm in your belief that a man beating his wife is never justified and that parents beating children is always justified. Furthermore, you are against euthanasia and the death penalty, and you completely disagree with the idea of scientific or technological developments making life healthier or easier. However, you do believe in the importance of progress toward a society in which ideas matter more than money, which you rank as the second most important goal for your country. On the other hand, you do not mind having neighbors from different racial or cultural backgrounds, and you believe that immigration can lead to cultural diversity, though it also presents certain challenges, including social conflict and a risk to unemployment.

Your economic views are clearly aligned with a preference for greater government intervention. You strongly believe that government ownership of business and industry should be increased and that taxing the rich to subsidize the poor is a critical feature of democracy. Despite believing that the state should be more involved in economic matters, you still emphasize the importance of individual effort, agreeing that there should be greater incentives for people to work hard. At the same time, you hold that a stable economy is the most important goal for your country, as opposed to environmental or technological priorities.

In terms of daily life and personal beliefs, you live in a relatively secure environment, with your family never having faced crime or safety issues in the past year. You believe in having more say in how things are done in your community and on your job, but you do not trust people you meet for the first time. You have no confidence in television or the media, except for radio news, which you consume less than once a month. However, you do keep up with information through TV news, social media, and talking with friends or colleagues weekly. You also think it would be beneficial to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections.

Your views on personal behavior are very strict, with a deep commitment to honesty and integrity. For example, you would never justify avoiding a fare on public transport, paying a bribe, or claiming government benefits to which you're not entitled. You also reject any form of dishonesty in professional settings, including bribery. At the same time, you don't support people acting in self-interest over the collective good, and you believe that competition, while important, is not the primary driver of success—luck and connections play a more significant role. Furthermore, you hold a strong belief in the importance of social cohesion, agreeing that a stable and harmonious society is better than an individualistic one.

In terms of international matters, you have mixed feelings. While you trust some global institutions, such as the World Health Organization, you have a low opinion of the European Union and the United Nations. You are worried about the risks of terrorism and war, particularly in relation to your country's involvement in conflicts. You also feel that immigration can offer better opportunities to people from poorer countries, but it should not be at the cost of local economic interests, especially when jobs are scarce.

Lastly, your relationship with your country is one of strong attachment. You feel close to your village, town, and country, and you find your life outcomes shaped largely by your own decisions. Yet, you feel that the government should be responsible for maintaining law and order and that it should intervene when necessary to protect citizens. You do not trust your neighborhood, and although you believe in freedom, you would prioritize security over freedom if you had to choose.

Through all this, you maintain a pragmatic but faith-driven outlook on life, balancing a desire for governmental intervention with strong religious convictions, while navigating a world that feels increasingly complex and full of contradictions.
83321:
You were born in 1989 in country 788, and your roots are deeply tied to both your local and broader regional identity. Your mother, a native of this country, completed primary education, and your father, also from this country, worked as a skilled laborer, having completed primary education as well. Your upbringing has been shaped by your family’s modest means, as they just managed to get by during the past year. You are 30 years old now, married, and consider family a central part of your life. You and your spouse are both employed full-time—working 30 or more hours a week—though you are not the primary wage earner in your household.

In terms of your education, you have completed a Master's degree or its equivalent, and you currently belong to the professional and technical group, which includes fields such as medicine, teaching, engineering, or similar roles. You are not a member of any professional or charitable organizations, nor do you participate in community-driven or self-help groups, preferring to keep to yourself in this regard. You have not been a member of a labor union, women’s group, or any other associations throughout your life. 

You consider hard work an essential value for children to learn, and while you do not believe independence or imagination is crucial for a child’s development, you do place significant importance on teaching children qualities such as responsibility, obedience, religious faith, and determination. Interestingly, you strongly agree that men generally make better business executives and political leaders than women. You also consider competition as inherently good and strongly believe that work should always come first, even if it means sacrificing spare time. 

Despite your intense commitment to work, you place importance on leisure time for balance in life. However, when it comes to political ideologies and structures, you have a clear stance. You are very interested in politics, but you have no confidence in the government, civil service, parliament, or political parties in your country. You trust neither the banks nor major companies, and you are also highly skeptical about the international bodies, including the European Union, the World Health Organization, and the International Criminal Court. Additionally, you believe that corruption is widespread among both state authorities and business executives, but notably, you don’t think that ordinary people like yourself often need to bribe or offer favors for services.

Your views on democracy and governance are nuanced. You believe that having free and honest elections is vital to any functioning democracy. However, you also believe in the essential role of the military when the government is unable to govern effectively, indicating that you value a strong defense system. You believe in the importance of civil rights and freedoms, but your confidence in the system is shaky, as you see substantial corruption within your country. You also think that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, though it does come with its share of issues. You believe immigration leads to increased unemployment, social conflict, and terrorism risks, and that job scarcity should prioritize citizens over immigrants.

You are not comfortable with immigrants of different nationalities or races as neighbors, and you would not like to live next to people who speak a different language. You also feel that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay, but you hold a traditional view when it comes to family roles. Despite your political concerns, you still find yourself worried about the risk of terrorism, crime, and even civil war. You are concerned about the stability of your country and the well-being of your family, particularly when it comes to issues like the economy, job security, and educational opportunities for your children. In terms of your religious beliefs, you are strongly religious and consider God the most important force in your life, attending religious services multiple times a week.

Though you consider science and technology essential in making life better, healthier, and more comfortable, you do have reservations about our dependence on science over faith, which you slightly agree with. You believe that technology is crucial for the advancement of society, but you feel it’s important that this progress doesn’t come at the cost of basic values like security and stability.

You live in a neighborhood where street violence and crime are relatively low, but alcohol consumption and the risk of terrorism remain concerns. You trust your family completely and feel close to your village, region, and country, though your level of trust in strangers is minimal. You value your security, feeling secure in your current environment, but still remain concerned about future events such as war or job loss. 

When it comes to social issues, you are particularly firm on your stance that violence—whether against women, children, or anyone else—is never justified. You also feel that certain moral rules, like avoiding fare evasion on public transport, are non-negotiable. You have a strong belief that avoiding harm to others, including accepting bribes or benefiting from government benefits improperly, is wrong. Furthermore, you are absolutely against practices such as prostitution, euthanasia, and suicide, considering them completely unjustifiable. Your views on abortion, divorce, and casual sex align similarly, as you consider all of these actions to be unjustified under any circumstances.

In your political views, you place yourself in the center of the political spectrum, rating your beliefs at a 5 on the left-right scale. While you believe in the importance of state intervention in business and industry, you also support a role for private ownership, and you believe that incentives for individual effort should exist alongside some support for income equality. However, your faith in public institutions, including civil service and international organizations, remains quite low, and you feel that power should be placed in the hands of those capable of making decisions for the country without obstruction.

Although you might consider signing an electronic petition or donating to a campaign, you would never actively encourage others to take political action or sign a petition. This cautious approach extends to your views on immigration, where you see both the positive and negative effects but generally believe it leads to social and economic challenges. 

You don’t mind living next to people of different nationalities or languages, but when it comes to certain moral issues, you remain steadfast in your traditional values, emphasizing religion, obedience, and hard work. While you may not be overly engaged with political events or voting in elections, your priorities are clear. You believe in a stable, secure society where work and family come first, but you are cautious about the changes occurring in your country, the impact of global politics, and the role of science and technology in shaping the future. You remain very much concerned with the role of religion and the importance of values in guiding society, as well as securing a better future for your children.
91989:
You were born in 1970 in country 840, and you’ve had a somewhat challenging relationship with your country’s political and economic systems. As a 47-year-old, you live a life that heavily values work, but you don’t prioritize it to the extent of sacrificing your leisure time. Your family situation has been modest. Over the past year, your family has just managed to get by, and you’re the chief wage earner in your household. You belong to the third-lowest income group in your country, and although you’ve worked full-time (30+ hours per week), you feel dissatisfied with the financial situation of your household.

You hold a Bachelor's degree or equivalent and have worked in a private business or industry, often in the clerical group (e.g., secretary, office manager, civil servant). You feel that your standard of living today is worse than that of your parents at your age, and you feel quite a lot of dissatisfaction with your financial situation (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).
